characters: ANCIENT RELAY SWITCHES THAT ILLUMINATE TINY RED LIGHTS ON
IN A DARK SAFETY NICHE IN THE WALL OF THE TUNNEL
SPLASHES OF BEAUTIFUL SHAPES AND BREATHTAKING COLORS
GRIDLOCK, SIRENS, CROWDS, COPS, BOMB SQUAD, NEWS, FBI, HE
THE NEXT TRAIN PULLS INTO THE STATION
HIS LENSES FOGGED FROM THE HUMIDITY ---
--- SIGNAL LIGHTS SNAPPING ON-AND-OFF LIKE STROBES
TRACK SWITCHES SHIFTING TRAINS ACROSS TRACK CROSSOVERS
THE TRAIN IS NO LONGER FLOATING THROUGH THE FOURTH DIMENS
POWER OF THE ENTIRE SYSTEM TOWARDS ---
SPARKS AND WIND WHIPPING PAST 468 STATIONS -
A SPIFFY NEW SHUTTLE SUBWAY TRAIN -
RENEE IS HOLDING AN INFANT WRAPPED IN A BLANKET ---
HORN BLAST YOU CAN FEEL IN YOUR HEART. A FLASH OF SEARING
--- AS THEY DETOUR THROUGH FOUR-DIMENSIONAL SPACE,
A SWIRLING WINDSTORM OF POWER, A VORTEX OF PURE ENERGY --
WE ARE IN A SUBWAY TUNNEL, (FLASHBACK CONTINUES)
TUPELO IS HIT WITH A WALL OF POWER AND WIND
THE SUP RVISOR FOR THIS STATION IS CRYTHEN BELL
DRAWING POWER FROM THE ENTIRE GRID OF THE SUBWAY SYSTEM
THE MAINTENANCE GUY LEAPS TO THE LEFT ---
THE MOTORMAN SLAMS OPEN THE COMPARTMENT DOOR -
THE POWER PASSES THROUGH THE STATION
METAL TRACK MAPS FROM 1950 IN GRIMY DISPATCH ROOMS -
STEEL WHEELS FOLLOW THE TRACK, AND WHEN THE TRACK CURVES
EVERYTHING LOUDER AND LOUDER AND THEN ---
INSTANT PULLBACK FROM INSIDE THE TRAIN AND ---
AS IF WE'RE IN THE VORTEX OF AN EXPLODING QUASAR IN DEEP
THE THIRD RAIL BUZZES WITH ELECTRICITY -
HERE COMES A TRAIN INTO THE STATION ---
WHEEL FLANGES TOUCH THE STEEL RAILS, (SPARKS FLY)
THE SIGNAL BOX HE WAS WORKING ON --- EXPLODES
THERE IS A STEADY DRIPPING SOUND NOW ---
--- POWERING AROUND THE CURVE OF TRACK 19
THE TRAIN SWEEPS PAST OUR VIEW
AN ANIMAL-LIKE SCREECH AS TINKERBELL INSTANTLY LEAPS TO H
IT GOES SOFT IN HIS HAND ---
OVERLAPPING AND FOLDING INTO EACH OTHER---
THAT HYPER-CLEAN ROOM AGAIN BECOMES THE REALITY
WE SEE QUICK-CUT MOMENTS, VISUAL FLASHES OF ---
AT THE END OF THE PLATFORM
IN THE TUNNEL FAR PAST THE PLATFORMS -
AT THE CENTER OF A HURRICANE -
THE ENTIRE ELEVATED PLATFORM BEGINS TO SHAKE -
TINKERBELL HAS JUST LEAPT OFF THE PLATFORM ---
THROUGHOUT A CITY OF TEN MILLION ---
ON THE OPPOSITE PLATFORM ACROSS THE TRACKS ---
TUPELO IS NOW INSIDE BOTH TRAINS ---
THE TRAIN GRINDS TO A STOP -
WHERE HE IS INSTANTLY SMASHED/CRUSHED BY AN EXPRESS TRAIN
THE TRAIN PULLS INTO THE NEXT STATION
THE DOOR BEHIND HIM SLAMS SHUT -
A SURGE OF POWER SHAKES THE TRAIN -
SHAPES POURS IN FROM THE FORWARD CARS AND IS ---
--- AN ELONGATED TUBE GROWING LONGER AND LONGER ---
TUPELO LOOKS OUT THE BACK DOOR ---
HE GRIPS THE HANDLE OF THE FRONT DOOR,
THE BOLT OF LIGHTNING ROARS TOWARDS CONEY ISLAND AND THE
TUPELO CRASHES DOWN ONTO THE TRACKS ---
AT THE SAME SPOT HE FELL IN THE MORNING ---
AND THEN CURLING INTO A PRETZEL-SHAPED MOEBIUS STRIP
INSIDE THE MOTORMAN'S COMPARTMENT NEXT TO TUPELO
WE ARE BACK IN THE BERGEN STREET STATION AT 6
A THRILL RIDE WHIPPING AROUND THE MOEBIUS KNOT/POWER SPOT
OFF WALLS, COMPRESSED AIR AND WATER PIPES SHATTERING, WHI
--- KEEP SCREECHING IN AND OUT OF TUNNELS ON THE CRISS-
CONNECTING ELECTRIC TRACK SENSORS BUILT IN 1904 THAT TRIP
THE TRAIN IS HIT BY A SEARING TORNADO OF HOT WIND ---
THE TRAIN ITSELF STRETCHES AND BECOMES A TUNNEL ---
ONCOMING SUBWAY SOUND GETTING LOUDER, AIR PRESSURE BUILDI
THERE IS A GENTLE ROCKING SOUND
FROM THE DARK TUNNEL OF TRACK 18 ---
WE FOLLOW THE BLUE-SPARKING, SCREECHING, SEARING-HOT CURR
---INDICATING THAT A TRAIN IS PASSING THROUGH THE SYSTEM
TWO COPS LEAP THE TURNSTILES IN PURSUIT,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHIE TUPELO, private school blazer, moves towards the lights reflecting off the dirty front window of the expre curving through an underground tunnel. As he presses his to the shaking, rattling front window ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - silvery tracks and dark tunnel walls hurl themselves at train - green lights all the way as the train rumbles acr a spiderweb of tracks and enters an even darker tunnel - cheap thrill ride for any kid through a parallel dimensio beneath the city streets.

dialogues.speaker: RICHIE AT THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: behind him the GRAFFITI-SPLASHED SUBWAY CAR is packed wit in power suits, women with Farah Fawcett hair and leg war and kids wearing Air Jordan - it's the 1980's. Richie pre closer to the dirt-smeared window. WE SEE: he hides a pen - a private school punk - and is carving his initials int shaking front door. Forming the "R" - the train SHUDDERS train SCREECHING as he presses down to form the "T”.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MOTORMAN'S COMPARTMENT NEXT TO TUPELO
dialogues.text: ---is THE MOTORMAN: 32, bushy moustache, big hair puffing of his Transit Authority cap - watching his station-marks enters 42nd Street station and expertly slows the train, the front of the lead car with the end of the platform. T train stops. At that instant ---

dialogues.speaker: THE MOTORMAN SLAMS OPEN THE COMPARTMENT DOOR -
dialogues.text: --- and LAUNCHES out at Richie ---

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMAN
dialogues.text: You little shit! Richie runs for the now-opened passenger doors --- but so many people are now flooding in that there's no way out - motorman gets a finger on Richie's collar - but Richie tw and breaks away - runs through the crowd to the back doo the angry motorman in pursuit ---

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Grab that private school son-of-a- bitch! Richie yanks open the door that leads to the next car.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN THE CARS
dialogues.text: Richie missteps, falls between the metal plates - TERROR! if the train's moving his leg is cut off now - he pulls o the door to the next car, the motorman reaching for him -

dialogues.speaker: IN THE NEXT CAR
dialogues.text: Richie swats away the hand, dashes off the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie rushes upstairs. Motorman does not follow. The con or signals from the middle car: we have a train to move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motorman swings back behind the controls. He eases th throttle, train moves into the tunnel. The motorman glanc the fresh "RT" scar on his front door. As if to a girlfri

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. THE CAMERA PANS FROM the "RT" graffiti to the motorman's name tag: SOLJAK.

dialogues.speaker: AN EXPLOSION OF SPARKS
dialogues.text: --- as a WELDER connects two lengths of steel. The white- streams of light REFLECT OFF --- --- that same old SOLJAK motorman's name tag, pitted and browned with age - pinned to the white shirt of ---

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL SOLJAK,
dialogues.text: his hair now short. No more moustache. He's put on weight  but Soljak is the blue collar guy who made good - having worked his way up from motorman to the chief operations officer of the Brooklyn Division. We are in

dialogues.speaker: A SUBWAY TUNNEL UNDER CONSTRUCTION
dialogues.text: --- jackhammers pounding, workers shouting, rainbows of w ing sparks - as Soljak gives a tour of this underworld to BOB, a NY Post reporter ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: The O-Line Shuttle. 18 years in the making. A shuttle line tying together all the threads of all 842 miles of the New York City subway system. I was here when this tunnel was still bedrock.

dialogues.speaker: BOB THE REPORTER
dialogues.text: When will the final rails actually be connected together?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: You mean like "in the old days" in Utah? (mimics hammering a spike) The celebration’s at City Hall tomorrow, Mayor’s gonna be there, gonna be some party. But the actual connection: later today. TERRELL WU, Soljak’s assistant, interrupts. Always interr

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: Chief ----

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: --- as long as I have no distractions. A CIVIL ENGINEER shows Soljak a blueprint. As he studies

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: You wanted me to notify you --- the other thing. Soljak okays the blueprint. To Bob the reporter:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Two o'clock this afternoon it's finished. Six o'clock tomorrow night - the party. Soljak heads for a work train. Terrell scrambles after hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me to tell you --- you didn't say you were going! No Chief, no ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even louder NOISE. A train barn where subway cars are rep refitted, cleaned. Soljak watches a line of older cars be assembled into a train - cars from the 1970’s and ‘80's. this some sort of Historic Celebration train? Bumpers sla together. Couplers connect. A SHOP BOSS counts off the ca

dialogues.speaker: SHOP BOSS
dialogues.text: Six --- seven --- eight --- The shop boss looks to Soljak. No smile. Shop boss unders SHOP BOSS (CONT’D) I hate this part of the job. The shop boss smacks the side of Car #8686 - the last car SHOP BOSS (CONT’D) (to mechanic) Cut it here. Leave this one behind.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: But ---

dialogues.speaker: SHOP BOSS
dialogues.text: Just do it. The mechanic uncouples the last car. Shop Boss to Soljak: SHOP BOSS (CONT’D) Want me to stash it somewhere? Hell, I’1l even hitch it up and send it out for a last ride. Soljak likes that idea. The shop boss turns a key, the to the last car open. Soljak climbs up into car #8686.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak peers into his old control compartment, touches cracked leather seat, the old-style control throttles.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Always so damn hot in here. Hard to imagine I used to live in this box five days a week. doors the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you don't miss being a motorman. A low rumble, the rest of the train that was attached to #8686 is moving away. Soljak drops the front window, watc the rest of his train disappear into a tunnel. Something boding about this - its tail-end streaked with tears of r

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (as the old train disappears) Running trains, working in this cage, do I miss it? --- Everyday. Then he notices a faded, almost-invisible scar in the fro door's steel: those initials --- "RT."

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL BLACKBOARD
dialogues.text: A hand writes the letter R - leaves a space - writes: T. Fills in the rest: R-ichard T-upelo. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: MEDIUM SHOT —- RICHARD TUPELO (R.T.) - DAY RICHARD TUPELO is now a handsome 29-year old teacher in b blazer and polo shirt - with the same mischievous swagger and those same style glasses as when he was 9. He faces h class with confidence and ease.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: My name is Richard Tupelo, and today you're going to forget everything you ever thought you knew ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL: no he's not teaching at Harvard, or at some small liberal arts haven - he's in the worst high school in the Bronx: slackers, wannabe gangsters, a smattering of tough Albanian immigrants ... and those are the good kids. This is not honorable volunteer work. Richard Tupelo does not to be here. While Soljak might be the working class guy w made good, Tupelo is the rich kid whose life derailed. TUPELO (CONT’D) Since I'm just subbing today, and none of you will ever see me again, let's all maybe try to have some fun. (This gets some attention -— some, very little, but some) Tell me one thing you've been taught this year that you don't believe. (no one responds) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TUPELO (CONT’D) Okay, I'll tell you something I don't believe: I don't believe anything in this room is real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That train of old rusted subway cars passes from darkness into daylight. EXT. BROOKLYN TRAIN YARD —- DAY The old train moves through acres of shiny new subway tra being readied for their runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old train continues onto a barge waiting at the pier, joining dozens of other old subway cars already packed on the barge - and chained together. Perhaps these venerable cars are heading for use in some other town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tugs pulls the barge into New York Harbor: subway cars floating past Manhattan, past The Statue of Liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAM! Tupelo crashes into a wall, bounces off, and then sl again against a wall - is he being beaten up by the stude REVEAL: he's throwing himself against the wall, again and This gets a few kids' attention. He gives himself a rest: TUPELO (CONT’D) Okay, so, if you learn one thing in science learn this: everything in the world is made up of atoms, tiny specks of matter that you can't see but which make up everything.

dialogues.speaker: ALBANIAN KID
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: This wall is not really hard, it's made up of trillions of floating atoms - and it's not "hard" until I press against it - the atoms in my body repelled by the atoms in the wall and if I pressed against this wall forever, imagine that, for the history of time --- (keeps pushing) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I lived forever and kept pressing against this wall there is a possibil- ity - of a moment - when the atoms in the wall might suddenly randomly arrange themselves so I'd go through the wall. Could happen right now. Or in a million years. Might never happen. But it could happen.

dialogues.speaker: SHARONA
dialogues.text: Like - you could walk through a wall?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Yeah. But something really, really different would have to be happening at just that moment in the universe to set up those circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: If you went through the wall would you be on the other side of the wall, or inside the wall?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Good question. Why aren't you in some brainiac school instead of this dung-heap? - and I'm not joking. Don't like to study?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Life is tough.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Well, kid, the second thing you need to learn is: as tough as you think your life is, for someone else it's even worse.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: (ignores that) If you went through the wall, what would it look like?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: All I know is this: when we leave this room, pull down the blinds, close the door, this classroom will not look like this classroom. This classroom, when no one's in here, is a swirling cloud of atoms that form this desk, this chair, this poster of Martin Luther King, with colors our eyes can't process and shapes you can't (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: begin to imagine and that's what this room really looks like until someone opens the door and looks in - and in that instant the human eye and the human brain will turn this swirling cloud of electrons-molecules-atoms into what we think of as "real." The kids are fascinated. Here is a guy who is not scared, bored, or patronizing to them. Tupelo is a brilliant teac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond New York Harbor the barge stops. Tug workers unhoo the chains that secure the old subway cars. The track pla form tilts and one by one, each car pulling the next car, SUBWAY CARS PLUNGE OVERBOARD - cries of metal, groans of steel as the old cars are unceremoniously dumped into the (NOTE: this is actually how they get rid of old subway ca

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSEA
dialogues.text: The drowning subway cars gasp and spit air as they sink t become part of an ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sad watery graveyard of forgotten history, silt and muc rising as each drowning car settles among the other rusti barnacle-covered hulks. One subway car comes to rest with its front end to us. An iridescent glow - its front door, motorman's window, headlights and identification plaque look like the face of a skull. Bubbles rise from its "mouth" and "nostrils." It looks --- very unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone else looks very unhappy: RENEE TUPELO, 29 - a nur very pretty in a Vermont-Montreal sort of way - Tupelo’s wife. She watches mothers push their children on the swin in a playground. A mother sees Renee. Waves hello. Renee backs off, heads across the street to Brooklyn Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak walks through a multi-level station. He loves this grand mechanism: trains on three levels moving in and out tunnels and platforms - like a giant clockwork at the hea of the city. Soljak pauses to watch - it’s as if he owns this place - and THROUGH HIS EYES ---

dialogues.speaker: WE SEE WHAT SOLJAK KNOWS
dialogues.text: ELECTRICITY SURGING ALONG THE MULTIPLE TRACKS’ THIRD RAI THE “SHOES” UNDERNEATH THE TRAINS PICKING UP THE CURRENT POWERING THE TRAINS AS --— SIGNAL LIGHTS COORDINATE WITH SWITCHES--——

dialogues.speaker: WHEEL FLANGES TOUCH THE STEEL RAILS, (SPARKS FLY)
dialogues.text: --- causing that ear-splitting SCREECH known to every one the 2 billion subway riders in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still amazed that this grand, decayed, complex machine wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo owns this classroom now - the kids gathered around as he demonstrates principles of perception with 3 cups a ball - the classic street hustle, expert slight-of-hand -

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Which one's the ball under. You saw it under Cup #1 - left-right, right to center, three cups - one has the ball - which one has the ball? They're all convinced that ---

dialogues.speaker: THE KIDS
dialogues.text: Left one! This one! Number One! Tupelo lifts cup #1: no ball. Groans, laughs. He shows th ball under Cup 3, again moves the cups around the table.  10.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We're all seeing the same thing right? Which one hides the ball? The kids all yell, call out, pointing to different cups.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: You got the ball in your hand. Tupelo's look: oh yeah? He lifts the first cup. No ball. the cup back down. Lifts the second cup. No ball. Lifts t third cup. No ball. He opens his hands: no ball. Huh? Whe the ball? Points to the first cup.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It's there. Trust me. Jamal lifts that cup again: now there's a ball there.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guess we didn't all see the same thing. That's the basis of rela- tivity: our relationship to and perception of what is happening defines our sense of what is real. Tupelo sees past the group around him, notices a scrawny face down on a desk. The kid is wearing a backpack covere scribbled note cards. Tupelo looks to the class: TUPELO (CONT’D) Okay ---. What's going on there?

dialogues.speaker: ALBANIAN KID
dialogues.text: You wanna trip into never-neverland - that's your tour guide. Lives in some other world already. Kids laugh. Tupelo moves to the slumped, apparently sleep figure, leans in close to read a card pinned to the backp

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: "Credit reports are good for 7 years True or False." (to the class) I'll take some help from anybody.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: We call her TinkerBell.

dialogues.speaker: SHARONA
dialogues.text: Teena something. That’s her real name.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Writes down crazy things she reads on walls, then clips 'em to herself. Tupelo reads other cards clipped to Tinkerbell:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: “If You See Something Say Something” “Who Will Be Miss Subway?” “WONDER BREAD” “Cry Then Bell” (to Jamal) If I came in here with a forklift, picked up the desk and her on it, and dumped her in the middle of a museum I'd get a "Genius Grant." Where’s she --- what's her ---?

dialogues.speaker: SHARONA
dialogues.text: If we knew that then she wouldn’t be called “Tinkerbell.”

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: But she's definitely alive, right? Jamal shrugs: maybe. Tupelo moves to touch TinkerBell. Hesitates. Looks to Jamal. Jamal nods: it’s okay to touch

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kid --- ? Tupelo gently touches Tinkerbell’s sleeve ---

dialogues.speaker: AN ANIMAL-LIKE SCREECH AS TINKERBELL INSTANTLY LEAPS TO H
dialogues.text: FEET — SCARING THE HELL OUT OF TUPELO - AND US! Jamal roars with laughter, knew this would happen. Tinker - blazing eyes, face like a feral cat - hisses at Tupelo:

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Don’t touch me!!

dialogues.speaker: AND THEN
dialogues.text: Tupelo jumps (so do we). Tupelo grabs his books, wants ou here even faster than the students do. Jamal cuts him off

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: You really believe any of what you told us - that nothing is real?  12.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (on his way out) Thanks for your little joke.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: C'mon, it was funny. Look: she’s okay. Tinkerbell does not look “okay” - glares at Tupelo.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Was that true what you said?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Next time your regular teacher cops a long weekend and they send me back here I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: (genuinely scary) We can make sure he never shows up.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Who can resist the spirit of young minds eager for education? Their eyes lock. Now only Tupelo and Jamal are left in th classroom - and Tinkerbell, who moves behind Jamal, her protector. Jamal touches Tupelo's sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Answer me. I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Do I really believe everything we see is some form of illusion that we call reality, an illusion we may more accurately understand sometime in the future? Do I actually believe that --- ? The Big Question. As Tupelo leans close to answer ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FLASH of POWER-ENERGY-SPEED as the #3 train rockets dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo, rocking with the rhythm, takes this subway world granted - believes it will get him home. Steel screeches, sounds - he ignores them. He looks up at the subway ads: “Credit reports are good for 7 years - True or False?"  13. Hmm - TinkerBell’s quote. And below that ad, the ominous 9/11 police department sign now in every car: IF YOU SEE SOMETHING SAY SOMETHING. The train speeds through COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY station. Tup lips tighten - bad memories. THE ROARING SUBWAY SOUND BEC EXT. BROOKLYN HOSPITAL —- DAY THE WAIL OF AN AMBULANCE - always some emergency in New Y - but no one on the street reacts. Exiting the hospital: Renee and two other nurses: her supervisor JUDY, and CARL Renee eyes the playground, Judy pulls her along with them

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: We’re going for a drink. And Renee, this time you’re coming.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it: she said yes.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: But it better be a place filled with loud nasty drunks.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: Sorry - I never drink at home. They head for a local tavern. Renee slows, sees: Tupelo coming up from a subway entrance. Looking for her.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Sorry girls, rain check, okay?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: You're ditching us for a guy?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: Does a husband count as a guy?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Next time. I promise. The friends continue across the street, polite nods to Tu - awkward moment, they know something. Renee smiles at hi instinct - what a smile, then the smile disappears. Cool:

dialogues.speaker: RENEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a surprise.  14.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Nice surprise? She puts her finger to his lips: Shh. Something very deep going on here. He locks her finger with his finger, moves it from his lips. Gives her a quick kiss. We notice their wedding rings - the identical simple bands. TUPELO (CONT’D) I had a very strange day. Want to get some dinner?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Let's just go home. That okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak, alone, on the promenade overlooking the harbor, watches tugboats and barges returning from the sea. The barges - once carrying old subway cars - are empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renee and Tupelo wait for a train. Quiet. A steady DRIPPI from somewhere. He takes her hand. She gazes at the track look as dark as when she was watching those kids in the p BANG! BANG! BOOM! - THEY BOTH STARTLE as a DRUMMER seekin tions starts pounding out a LOUD BEAT on plastic water ju Tupelo puts his arm around the edgy Renee. She rests her on his shoulder. She fights back tears ---

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Richard --- He fears what might be coming. She begins to speak, then surprise - she pulls him into a desperate kiss. WHOOSH-GROWL - an EXPRESS ROARS through the station as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak crunches blueprints, ready to explode:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What do you mean it's not done? I left for two hours - it should have taken ten minutes!

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: I begged you: Don't leave. You leave, nothing goes right. If you'd stayed---  15.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What is the problem?

dialogues.speaker: CIVIL ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Wrong joint was delivered.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Then get the right joint.

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: It's in Jersey City.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Goddammit! Finish this now!

dialogues.speaker: CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: (takes a step back) Can't get delivery ‘til tonight and if I gotta keep a crew on, gonna cost---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I don’t care! The Mayor’s flying back from China for this - and tomorrow is the best day of my life. If it's not, it’s gonna be the worst day of yours. Got that? I've given 30 years to this system. This is my wife, my family, my life, and anyone who gets in my way ---

dialogues.speaker: CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: Okay! It'll get done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Renee pulls on jeans. Washes her face. Looks away from th mirror. Sad - wishes she wasn’t. Tupelo - they’ve just ma love - watches her from the bed. Love. Oldies on the radi

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Never told me about your day.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Got to find something else to do.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: What about the thing in Vegas? On the living room table: schematic drawings and a model car on a platform surrounded by shards of mirrors.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: He just needs the trick. Doesn't need me to build it.  16.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Still, you should go out there.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: He'll invite us both out for the opening.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: But you need a vacation --- (softly, sweetly) From me. Tupelo, out of bed, wraps himself in the sheet, follows h into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Don't say that, please.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: How'd your cousin ever get into magic? We realize what he’s building is a miniature Vegas stage

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It's not that different from physics. On the radio the Go-Go's sing “Our Lips Are Sealed.” Tupe Renee glance at each other - some old joke between them - can’t stay sad. As the Go-Go’s sing their garbled chorus Lips Are Sealed...’ Renee playfully sings misheard lyrics

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: “Alex the Seal ---"

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: See? - my version is better. Any- way, that’s what it sounds like. The song keeps playing - brightens the room, and them ---

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Be honest - you didn’t think those were the words. The song is “Our Lips are Sealed" so it’s obvious---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Obvious maybe to a girl.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: What would “Alex the Seal” mean?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Something very heavy, and very deep.  17.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: (jumps and sings) “Alex the Seal, Alex the Seal”--- Her voice drifts. Tupelo SEES IN THE MIRRORS: Renee looki across the apartment at a locked door. The sadness return

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (goes to her) We can't keep it closed forever.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: It's like it all never happened.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Let me - I can pack her things.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: She had a beautiful life. She did. That should be the memory. Renee doesn’t respond. Goes to the locked door. Touches i TUPELO (CONT’D) Let me take care of everything. While you're at work.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: I don't want that. Not until you---.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: What? See things your way?

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: She had a terrible life. Just agree with me, okay? I need that.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We're allowed to handle things dif- ferently.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: I know. We handle things differently - (touches his shoulder) --- and that's what going to kill us. She goes back into their bedroom. Closes that door. Not a slam, just a very chilling CLICK. Tupelo now left alone. He looks at that first door. CAMERA MOVES TOWARDS the dar  18. keyhole, taking us closer, closer - TENSION BUILDS and ju when we could see through the hole and into the other sid SCREAM-SCREECH-WHOOSH-GROWL ---—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --- a subway train BLASTS out of a dark tunnel and ROARS the station. Tupelo and Renee dash down the steps to catc

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Tupelo and Renee, standing in the noisy, surprisingly old subway car - seems neither slept last night. It’s early, only a dozen other PASSENGERS are in their car including: A young EXEC reading Advertising Age ... a CHINESE KITCHE WORKER ... an ART STUDENT ... a red-haired MODEL with no makeup reading Vogue ... a FAT GUY with court papers ... three scattered HOMELESS GUYS ... and yet another SUBWAY DRUMMER pounding away on a plastic container. Renee's tense. Tupelo tries to calm her:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Alex the Seal. She forces a weak smile, remembers something, checks her

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Forgot my keys.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I'm just filing hours today, and sending that design to my cousin. I'll be home when you get home. Something grabs Tupelo's pant cuff. A rat? - Tupelo pulls away - looks down: it's a little KID IN A STROLLER. Tupel goofs with the kid. The kid laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: You would have been a great father.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I was a great father.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: For six weeks I was a great father. And maybe I'll get another chance.  19.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We can try. What he said burns her. He touches her, wants her happy. Instead:

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: We need to be away from each other.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Renee ---

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: When the train stops I need to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Renee ---

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Get off the train or I will --- SCREAM OF STEEL WHEELS AGAINST STEEL TRACK as the train enters the next station. CONDUCTOR’S VOICE Bergen Street. Next stop Atlantic Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STATION
dialogues.text: Train doors open. Mother with kid exits. Tupelo gets off. were in the rear car. From the platform Tupelo looks back Renee. She can't believe what just happened - now feels a reaches her hand to him, truly loves him, WANTS HIM BACK, CONDUCTOR’S VOICE Stand clear of the closing doors. TRAIN DOORS SLAM SHUT. Tupelo smacks the door with his hand - wants in. Too late Train CHUNKS, starts to move.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TRAIN -
dialogues.text: Renee rushes to the rear window as the train pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PLATFORM -
dialogues.text: Tupelo raises a hand to her when ---  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --- stumbles forward AND FALLS INTO THE TRACK PIT

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO CRASHES DOWN ONTO THE TRACKS ---
dialogues.text: --- into the muck between steel rails - rats scurry as -

dialogues.speaker: SOMEONE RUNS AWAY -
dialogues.text: chasing the train ---

dialogues.speaker: TWO COPS LEAP THE TURNSTILES IN PURSUIT,
dialogues.text: chasing a YOUNG PUNK in a black jacket and backpack who LEAPS ONTO THE BACK OF THE RUSHING-AWAY TRAIN -— latching onto the rear chains to hold on as---

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: reacts to seeing Tupelo knocked into the pit, then sees A WILD CREATURE SUDDENLY LATCHED ONTO THE TRAIN -— --- a psychotic young face fills the window: TinkerBell. THE SUBWAY TRAIN — curves into the dark of the tunnel. The SCREECH of scrapi

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TRACK PIT -
dialogues.text: Tupelo - feeling in the muck for his glasses, finds them

dialogues.speaker: THE THIRD RAIL BUZZES WITH ELECTRICITY -
dialogues.text: - the main rails beginning to vibrate - Tupelo blinks to his bearings - am I alive? am I dead? - his glasses filth he seems in some timeless other dimension of the city, wh

dialogues.speaker: HE IS THRUST FORWARD
dialogues.text: HIS LEGS AND FEET PULLED THROUGH THE MUCK as he’s GRABBED the cops and a FARE CLERK who pull him up out of the pit.

dialogues.speaker: COP 1, (OFFICER GARRETT)
dialogues.text: You okay?  21.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: My wife's on the train. Is she ---?

dialogues.speaker: COP 2
dialogues.text: Get a look at who did it?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: You got pushed onto the tracks. THE NEXT TRAIN ROARS INTO THE STATION - at this hour trai pull into stations every minute. Had Tupelo stayed in the he's dead now. The cop’s on his intercom:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop the #3 coming into Atlantic Avenue - we got a Code 2-40 riding the back!

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TRAIN
dialogues.text: A FLASH OF IMAGES as Renee and Tinkerbell's eyes meet thr the back door's scratched glass. Renee saw her bump Tupel onto the tracks - wants to kill her - tries to get at her but the door is locked --- --- and TinkerBell’s face is now so vulnerable it breaks heart --- and now Renee sees her as a scared child hangin onto the back of a speeding train - now wants to help ---

dialogues.speaker: A LOOK OF ANIMAL HORROR
dialogues.text: comes over TinkerBell's face as --- TINKERBELL'S POV: INSIDE THE SPEEDING SUBWAY CAR -— --- a TORNADO-LIKE STORM OF BARELY-IMAGINED COLORS AND

dialogues.speaker: SHAPES POURS IN FROM THE FORWARD CARS AND IS ---
dialogues.text: RUSHING TOWARDS US ---— --- towards the unaware Renee - is this real or some psychotic Tinkerbell vision? - the storm of FRIGHTENING SHAPES and COLORS about to overtake Renee when --- INT. ATLANTIC AVENUE STATION —- DAY Commuters wait impatiently for the #3 train. Hear the SCR and ROAR as flanges hit rails in the curving tunnel --- t RUMBLE of the train brings some waiting commuters closer the edge of the platform while others back away and then  22.

dialogues.speaker: WHOOSH
dialogues.text: --- blasts through the station - pulling newspapers out o hands, tossing hats, sending magazines from the news-kios flying --- and just as quickly disappears down the tunnel Lots of "what the fuck ---?-'s --- but before there's a consensus of "what the fuck?" did just happen---

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT TRAIN PULLS INTO THE STATION
dialogues.text: It's rush hour - and people are late - so everyone on the platform just gets on this next train - and this train leaves - and the platform is now empty --- AS COPS RUSH DOWN ONTO THE PLATFORM --—— --- to find: no train, no waiting passengers, no TinkerBe only a Pakistani news-seller picking up the newspapers an tickets blown from his kiosk by the mysterious gust of wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SEARING BLAST OF LIGHT. The Contractor turns to Soljak:

dialogues.speaker: CONTRACTOR
dialogues.text: It's done. Soljak looks over to workers making the final welds on th shuttle track. The station clock: 6:23. A gruff whisper:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Done. First time in 112 years: the entire tangle of the New York City Subway System is tied together --- Soljak does not seem triumphant. More an "is that all the is?" expression as he turns to Bob the Reporter who holds a digital recorder to capture Soljak's every word:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --- all 25 different lines, all 468 stations, and now it's all hooked together in one big knot - and we did it. Bravo. But if I ask for one more fire extinguisher or to change some wiring from 1930 I still need twenty pages of paperwork. The people deserve better, the workers deserve better, and this old system deserves better. A hand grabs Bob's recording device, a hand that belongs  23. MICHELLE MURPHY, a hot-looking 30ish corporate-type---

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: What the Chief of Operations, Brooklyn Division - who is scheduled to retire this week, I believe - means to say is that when he started things were very different - very simple - and now we're in the 21st Century. (takes the reporter's hand) Michelle Murphy - mayor's office. She takes the digital recorder away from Bob. Bob reacts. MICHELLE MURPHY (CONT’D) Didn't you still want that interview with the Mayor on Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: BOB THE REPORTER
dialogues.text: I never - I have an interview with the mayor? (likes that) Let me show you how to erase that. As Bob the Reporter erases Soljak's quote from the digita recorder, Terrell pulls Sojak aside:

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: Uh Chief: we got a problem at Bergen Street Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The northbound platform and local track has been closed. Tupelo, emergency blanket over his shoulders, fumbles wit his cell phone as OFFICER GARRETT questions him.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: You said you’re a teacher - the creep who pushed you was a kid. Any reason for a kid to push you? Tupelo, somewhat in shock, ignores that, his mind elsewhe

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I had a little fight with my wife, got off the train, then I tried to get back on and next thing I'm --- I need to call her - tell her I’m okay - she must have gotten off at the next stop - can you call her?  24.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: No, but if she got off at Atlantic she’1l be back here in a minute. But the kid who pushed you --- (reading his notes) --- 'bout this high, maybe 15 - grabbed a can of yellow spray paint out of a hardware store on Bergen street, we were chasing her, jumped the turnstile ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: So you were chasing him? He wasn't trying to kill me. He bumped me? It was an accident?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: Not “him” - “her.”

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Her?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: And her jacket and backpack: cover- ed with all kinds of crazy weird notes. Can you help me out here?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Tinkerbell? Officer Garrett smiles politely. EMS GUYS arrive with med kit, pull on gloves.

dialogues.speaker: EMS DUDE
dialogues.text: This the guy? Sir, look into this light. Can you tell me your name?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Richard Tupelo. A southbound train BLASTS in from the opposite direction. Stops across the tracks at the opposite platform. Tupelo stands. Sees people get off. Train leaves. No Renee.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: Maybe she didn’t see what happened.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Can someone take me to the Hospital Center? She works there.  25.

dialogues.speaker: EMS DUDE
dialogues.text: (to the cop) All right with you, we done here?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, what the hell, the guy’s half wacko, can’t tell us any- thing, besides --- (points to surveillance cam) We got it all on tape. The southbound ROARS out of the station - becoming a SMEA light and color disappearing into the tunnel darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Renee works. Busy, under-staffed, and supervisor Nu Judy has lost her patience with Tupelo.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I called home, she’s not there. Called her mother, not there.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: For the third time, Richard, she's not here - and whatever you two need to work out, I understand, but I am none too happy that she hasn’t shown up for work. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (spots the friend) Carla - did you see her? You take the same train, right?

dialogues.speaker: CARLA
dialogues.text: I came in early today.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: Richard, she is not here! We're not hiding her. And you look like shit - go get yourself clean!

dialogues.speaker: EMS DUDE
dialogues.text: Mr. Tupelo, you need to come with us. On the marker board that lists nurses working this shift Renee’s name is being erased. AS HER NAME DISAPPEARS ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MESSENGER leaves documents on the desk of an empty cubi  26. the exec who should be here hasn’t shown for work. No big

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner is screaming in Chinese, pointing to a sink fil with pots. We only understand: “no dishwasher.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students at work at their easels. One easel is empty.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Where’s Claire? New boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed, hellish. The JUDGE moves through cases quickly.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Mister Mizrahi not with us this morning? Judgement against him. Next case ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MODELS - one Blonde, one Black - and one crazed PHOTO

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: She always late! I don’t need her. Get me a redhead. Any redhead

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One homeless guys barks at another who holds a DONATION s

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS GUY
dialogues.text: Where’s Slim? This is his spot.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGHOUT A CITY OF TEN MILLION ---
dialogues.text: Several dozen random people at random locations are missi absent, or late. But no reason for panic. Yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops, transit officials and investigators, reporters, a g ladder takes down a surveillance camera. Soljak looks to (a drippy ceiling), his voice loud enough for everyone to

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: May we re-open this station? I’ve been re-routing trains for two hours which which has backed up (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: my system for five hours. Read the signs, people: STAY BACK FROM THE TRACKS! So some jerk can’t read, fell in, and then he climbed out - so nothing happened!

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE MARASCHINO
dialogues.text: Attempted Murder. He was pushed.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: If he was pushed find who pushed him. You got all your new TV cameras so go watch TV. Let me get this system back on schedule. Somebody. Please. No one wants to make a decision. Until she appears:

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Let's get this station re-opened.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: (explains to the detective) Mayor's Director of Operations, and campaign director --- a lotta juice.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Michelle. She nods like a queen, taps her watch:

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: The mayor’s plane lands in four hours and we have a very important evening so let’s not have any more screw ups. Is that clear Mr. Soljak?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I didn’t fall on the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: You're starting to look like you did. Get some sleep. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: This is my home.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Not for long, but if you want that big cushy consultant job when you retire make sure nothing else gets in the way today. She marches away. Terrell whispers to Soljak:  28.

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: You need to pay attention to what I've been trying to tell you, Chief - and please don’t yell at me.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Then don't tell me things that are insane. What do you mean a #3 is missing? Terrell, be very precise: define the word "missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gloomy spiderweb of tracks and tunnels, one of those sp where several threads of the system connect. TWO SUBWAY MAINTENANCE WORKERS - hard hats and orange stiped vests - are repairing a light signal. Left and right of them SUBW TRAINS, SPARKS FLYING, ROAR PAST THEM in several directio These guys barely notice - it's where they work.

dialogues.speaker: MAINTENANCE GUY
dialogues.text: Four-hour work order here and it turns out we just have to change a bulb.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY THE HELPER
dialogues.text: So we take the rest of the day off?

dialogues.speaker: MAINTENANCE GUY
dialogues.text: No. We don't take the rest of the day off. And next time you come to work stinking of beer I'm writing you up. Get me a #28 bulb. Jimmy the Helper heads down the track to a work kit. He stops. Senses something. The switches that run parallel t the track are starting to click. He turns to his boss.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY THE HELPER
dialogues.text: Uh, this track is shut down now, right?

dialogues.speaker: MAINTENANCE GUY
dialogues.text: Get me the bulb!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY THE HELPER
dialogues.text: Boss - the switches are flicking.

dialogues.speaker: MAINTENANCE GUY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you? The track’s shut down, its been down for 2 hours.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY THE HELPER
dialogues.text: Check this out, boss. It's humming.  29. The maintenance guy, now even more annoyed, steps down fr his ladder onto the track bed. Sees - hears - the action the pre-1940's switches clicking along the track. Snaps h walkie-talkie off his belt. SUDDENLY - BEHIND HIM ---

dialogues.speaker: THE SIGNAL BOX HE WAS WORKING ON --- EXPLODES
dialogues.text: Showering him with sparks. He winces, looks at the box, looks at Jimmy the Helper.

dialogues.speaker: MAINTENANCE GUY
dialogues.text: That's not possible. The power is off.

dialogues.speaker: --- KEEP SCREECHING IN AND OUT OF TUNNELS ON THE CRISS-
dialogues.text: CROSSING AND PARALLEL WEB OF TRACKS --- as the maintenanc guy barks into his walkie-talkie: MAINTENANCE GUY (CONT’D) Jackson! Track 18 DeKalb Avenue is shut down, right? (a garble of static) Fucking equipment! Jackson! Maintenance Guy and his helper can FEEL the power surging through the stretch of track they stand on ---

dialogues.speaker: --- SIGNAL LIGHTS SNAPPING ON-AND-OFF LIKE STROBES
dialogues.text: RED-YELLOW-GREEN --—

dialogues.speaker: THEY, (AND WE)
dialogues.text: --- they look to each other - there's no train there - bu the RUMBLING THROB OF POWER GROWS CLOSER, LOUDER - THE SC - and THEY FEEL AN ON-RUSHING SURGE OF AIR PRESSURE --- MAINTENANCE GUY (CONT’D) What the --- get off the track ---

dialogues.speaker: GET OFF THE TRACK
dialogues.text: JIMMY THE HELPER DIVES TO THE RIGHT as---

dialogues.speaker: THE MAINTENANCE GUY LEAPS TO THE LEFT ---
dialogues.text: --- onto the empty Track 19 ----  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide-eyed horror as he sees THE SCREECHING EXPRESS TEARIN

dialogues.speaker: HIS BOSS TO SHREDS ---
dialogues.text: --- and then Jimmy FEELS a POWERFUL CURRENT OF TORNADO-WI

dialogues.speaker: FLYING PAST HIM ---
dialogues.text: --- disappearing into the darkness - and then all those strobing signal lights on Track 18 instantly go dark. The clicking of signals stops. The tunnel falls silent -- except for Jimmy the Helper's SCREAM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deep, angry undersea sound. The drowned old subway cars shift and settle among the debris of a hundred years of discarded cars, tugboats, machines and technology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now the subway world should seem the norm with it's da tunnels and tiled passageways lit by yellow and florescen light - and the world above the subway - the surface worl should seem almost too bright, too crisp, almost surreal. Tupelo EXITS THE HOSPITAL. Sees the playground. Heads for catches the eye of a mother pushing her kid on a swing.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Hey it’s you. How’s Renee?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It’s tough, you know. Has she been around? I know she comes here.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I seen her. I don’t think she should come here though.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: When’d you see her? Today?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: What about today? This morning?  31. No luck. Then: SIRENS grab his attention. EMS and police converge on one of the several Downtown Brooklyn subway entrances. Tupelo senses trouble, moves quickly across gridlocked traffic to ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the worker was hit by the train. Now crawling with investigators. Tupelo charges downstairs, is stopped by a

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Station's closed.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Please go back upstairs. Now Soljak and Terrell charge downstairs, passing them. Tupelo hears Soljak would

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: First a guy on the tracks, a train missing, now this? Why today? This is my day.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (follows them) I'm the guy who fell on the tracks. This morning. At Bergen Street. like to strangle Tupelo.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: You look fine, get yourself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Which train is missing? The #3, this morning? My wife was on that train and she's missing too. She's missing and now the train’s miss- ing? What the hell’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I just got here, pal. There’s been an accident - nothing to do with the #3 train. If you would give my associate a number where you can be reached I will have someone call you.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: What’s that mean: “missing train”?  32.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: It’s not actually --- it’s a cler- ical error. We’ve been re-directing trains all morning. Thanks to you.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: But where is it? Sojak, losing patience, points to the iconic NYC Subway m

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Sir, we got a closed system - we don't connect to Amtrak or the Long Island Railroad - so our train is not in the Hamptons for the weekend, it's not on its way to Cleveland - it's in the city somewhere so the farther it gets from the point it left from the sooner it's gonna come back. It's in the system, okay? - and whatever passen- gers were on it this morning are long gone and off on their merry ways.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You mean the passengers might have been dumped somewhere? Soljak sees: the mangled body being removed from the trac Cops surround the horror-stricken Jimmy the Helper. Then- THE SOUND OF AN ONCOMING TRAIN - THE SCREECH! --— Everyone shivers. Jimmy presses back against the wall. TERROR. Soljak heads towards the action, barking ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I thought this track was shut down! The rumble gets louder. LOUDER. LOUDER ----

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everybody off the tracks! What the---!? Workers and EMS guys scramble onto the platform. As ---

dialogues.speaker: WHOOSH ----
dialogues.text: A POWER RUSHES THROUGH THE CENTER TRACKS, kicking up wind that sends trash flying. But the (0.S.) NOISE is clearly from the unseen level below, but as THE NOISE passes ---  33.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CENTER TRACKS
dialogues.text: --- a strange metallic shimmering in the air - that just quickly disappears. All eyes turn to Soljak. Quick answer

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Pressure from the IRT, or maybe the F Train - right beneath us - kicks up the steel dust - happens. (to Terrell) Go downstairs and find out what train just passed, how fast it was going, and why. As Terrell heads for the staircase down to the lower leve

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (to Soljak) That train that's missing, that my wife is on. Any contact with the conductor, the motorman?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (to anyone) I thought this guy was gone.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You never took my phone number. Remem- ber? You were going to call me.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Somebody take his phone number and get him out of here --- (looks around) Where's Terrell?

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE TO LOWER LEVEL
dialogues.text: Terrell, charging downstairs, runs into an angry TRANSIT WORKER rushing upstairs ---

dialogues.speaker: TRANSIT WORKER
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on up there? We just got a shower of plaster and asbestos raining down on our heads!

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: We got nothing upstairs! What just blasted through down here?  34.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSIT WORKER
dialogues.text: Down here? Nothing! Just a blast of wind and that train upstairs that must have been doing like 80!

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: But there was no train up there! It was down here! They exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS ---
dialogues.text: Tupelo gives his number to Soljak. Takes a card from Solj

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: When you hear from her, and you will, call me. Now you have to leave.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: (sees Tupelo) You're back again?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Please make him leave. Officer Garrett escorts Tupelo to the stairs. Tupelo sees clock: 9:30 a.m. To the cop:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Officer, help me. My wife’s been missing for like three hours and---

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: We can’t do anything for 24 hours. A child - you could report it now, but she’s an adult - gotta wait. Trust me: she’1ll show up. Tupelo takes a last glance around the station, looks acro the four sets of tracks, and freezes --- SEES:

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OPPOSITE PLATFORM ACROSS THE TRACKS ---
dialogues.text: --- in the shadows, watching, listening: TINKERBELL (she longer has her note-covered backpack). She sees Tupelo se her, squirrels away into darkness. Tupelo yells:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Stop! That's her! Soljak, everyone hears - turns - this is good news ---  35.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Your wife? You see your wife?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: No. Not my wife --- (points, but no one's there) Tinkerbell!

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: “Tinkerbell”!!?? Get that maniac out of here! And keep him out! The cop hustles Tupelo up towards the street, but now he doesn't have to prod him, Tupelo pushes away and races tw steps at a time up to ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy, noisy, chaotic, ambulances, police cars, TV news va --- normal New York. Yellow CAUTION tape now closes off t subway entrances. Tupelo looks left, right - subway entra for eight different routes at every corner of five conver streets. But no Tinkerbell. Officer Garrett catches up:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: The kid who pushed you - you saw her?! As the cop calls for backup ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO SEES TINKERBELL ---
dialogues.text: --- just a glimpse, rushing down into a different station across the avenue. Tupelo wants to follow, but the cop ha his arm.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need a detailed description.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Let me go, I'll catch her. She was on that train! Let me talk to her. I'll find out ---

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: That's our job, not yours. Tupelo does not want to lose Tinkerbell, breaks away from cop and charges across the street ---

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! Stop! Get back here! --- Tupelo dodging cars until ---  36.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO COLLIDES WITH A TAXI ---
dialogues.text: --- goes down hard, rolls, gets back up - hands bruised, cheek cut - races down into a subway entrance that leads

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: platforms and tunnels that are completely separate from where the accident took place. Tupelo swipes his Metrocar at the turnstile - doesn't register - swipes it again ---

dialogues.speaker: HERE COMES A TRAIN INTO THE STATION ---
dialogues.text: --- and there's Tinkerbell, pacing, skittish - train stop doors open, she gets on, but ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO'S ENTRY CARD DOESN'T WORK ---
dialogues.text: --- he yells into the noise ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Hold that train! --- and here comes the cop! Tupelo leaps the turnstile, rushes for the train --- a TEENAGER holds the door open - Tupelo gets in. TRAIN DOORS CLOSE --- TRAIN STARTS TO MOV --- the cop chases but it's too late ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo sees the cop pointing to the train as it pulls awa The teenager sizes up Tupelo:

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGER
dialogues.text: Nice. Tupelo moves forward through the train to find Tinkerbell Gets to the door to the next car. Pulls the handle. Locke Sees through the windows into the next car. Crowded. Tupe spots Tinkerbell. He readies to make his move as

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN PULLS INTO THE NEXT STATION
dialogues.text: Tupelo goes to the exit door, nervous energy. Train stops Doors open. He bursts out onto ---  37.

dialogues.speaker: THE STATION PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Tupelo sees Tinkerbell dash downstairs to a connecting li

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO PUSHES THROUGH THE CROWD
dialogues.text: to catch her, and the way he looks - cut, bruised - peopl out of his way.

dialogues.speaker: HE REACHES THE LOWER PLATFORM
dialogues.text: as a train pulls into the station. People pour out onto t platform. Tinkerbell gets on at the front. DOORS CLOSING -— ---but Tupelo forces his way in - two cars behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TRAIN
dialogues.text: That sign: IF YOU SEE SOMETHING SAY SOMETHING. Blacks, Wh Indians, Mexicans, Jews, Chinese - all watching Tupelo. CONDUCTOR’S VOICE Next stop Manhattan, Whitehall Street. Tupelo goes to the subway map beside the door, the car ro side-to-side as he traces the yellow-colored route with h bloody finger - it connects to the red-colored line to Th Bronx at 42nd Street. He knows where she's heading. Tupelo pushes forward through the other riders to the fro of the swaying car, pulls open the door, steps forward --

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: --- holding his balance as the train rockets through the curving Montague Street East River Subway Tunnel. Tupelo looks down at the connecting step-plates - sawing each other. He reaches across the step-plates, pulls the door latch t the next car. CLICK. It’s locked.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR BEHIND HIM SLAMS SHUT -
dialogues.text: --- now he's between cars. He muscles the forward door - it won't open. He starts to retreat back when ---  38.

dialogues.speaker: A SCREECH OF METAL ---
dialogues.text: --- as the train curves and brakes apply, SPARKS FLYING a the train SQUEALS - STEEL WHEELS JAMMING, THE TRAIN JERKI

dialogues.speaker: THE MOMENTUM CARRYING TUPELO FORWARD ---
dialogues.text: --- between the cars, slamming Tupelo into the forward do his leg slipping between the step-plates - he pulls his l up - the plates SLAM together as ---

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN GRINDS TO A STOP -
dialogues.text: Tupelo falls to the side into the chain guards, DROPS HIS GLASSES, catches them, puts them on ---

dialogues.speaker: HIS LENSES FOGGED FROM THE HUMIDITY ---
dialogues.text: --- EVERYTHING A STRANGE BLUR as he reaches back to the d that opens, can't find the handle, gets it, pulls - OPENS he stumbles into the car, wipes his glasses, FINDS:

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STALLED SUBWAY TRAIN ---
dialogues.text: People are picking themselves off the ground, cursing, fi ing their spilled belongings when ---

dialogues.speaker: THE GENERATOR SHUTS DOWN ---
dialogues.text: --- air conditioning stops. GROANS from the riders. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FLICK-FLICK-FLICK ----
dialogues.text: --- one-by-one THE LIGHTS GO OUT IN THE TRAIN plunging al the cars into DARKNESS. CRIES, MORE CURSES. Tupelo’s eyes adjust to the GLOW of reflected signal lights from outsid train: SMEARS of red, yellow, green on the filthy windows --- they’re stalled in a tunnel, this is as bad as it get Usually. But now it gets worse ---

dialogues.speaker: THERE IS A STEADY DRIPPING SOUND NOW ---
dialogues.text: --- on the roof of the train from the tunnel ceiling, the

dialogues.speaker: A SURGE OF POWER SHAKES THE TRAIN -
dialogues.text: --- a HORRIBLE WRENCHING SOUND and --- THE DOORS ON BOTH SIDES OF THE SUBWAY TRAIN --—  39.

dialogues.speaker: ALL SUDDENLY OPEN
dialogues.text: ---people who were leaning on the doors tumble towards darkness, others catch them, pull them back, people crush ing closer into the center of the car which is now like an open aluminum can stalled in the dark tunnel ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - a fevered announcement from the conductor is so garbled with static that it only creates more panic. And then, fr somewhere at the back of the train: "you hear that?" - "shh" - "shut up!" - --- the frightened riders fall into a nervous silence - i the dark, wide-open train the riders strain to hear A DEE BASS NOTE - then they hear THE DISTANT SOUND OF: AN (0.S.) ONCOMING TRAIN --- coming from somewhere deep i the tunnel, coming closer, ON THE SAME TRACK. Wild Panic.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO LOOKS OUT THE BACK DOOR ---
dialogues.text: --- a distant swirling glow, something is coming --- THE

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Down! Everyone down on the floor! --- SOUND COMING CLOSER - THE SCREECH! --- but instead of the smash/impact of a train wreck ---

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN IS HIT BY A SEARING TORNADO OF HOT WIND ---
dialogues.text: that BLASTS right through the stalled train as if an invisible train is slicing through this dimension ---

dialogues.speaker: A SWIRLING WINDSTORM OF POWER, A VORTEX OF PURE ENERGY --
dialogues.text: --- aglow with hot steel dust - TEARING clothing, CRACKIN glass, SLAMMING people to the floor, walls, and into each other as it SWEEPS through each car of the train. And the

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE ---
dialogues.text: the sparkling steel dust becoming blackened soot. THE DOO ALL SLAM SHUT AGAIN --- the lights crackle back on. Peopl crying, bleeding, then ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and crawls into the Whitehall Street station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors of the battered train open, people flee for the exi collapse on the platform, the totally-freaked conductor b

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: This train is now out of service!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the crowd, looking for Tinkerbell. She's gone. But he

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TUNNEL FAR PAST THE PLATFORMS -
dialogues.text: --- a haze of steel dust creates a shimmering negative-im of the old subway car that passed through this space. Mak his skin crawl. The image settles into soot and evaporate

dialogues.speaker: FROM DEEP IN THE TUNNEL ---
dialogues.text: --- that DEEP BASS NOTE echoes - moving on.

dialogues.speaker: IN A DARK SAFETY NICHE IN THE WALL OF THE TUNNEL
dialogues.text: Tinkerbell also hears the sound. FEAR. She scribbles on a scrap of paper the number she saw on the phantom train: 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grimy glassed-in underground office that looks out at a network of subway tracks. Soljak is interrogating Jimmy, drunk guy who was working with the killed electrician.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: So, you felt "a wind ---

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: And the signal lights started flashing, and the relays ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: But the current was turned off.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: On our track, yeah, and then --- Jimmy starts sobbing. Soljak is disgusted:  41.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: You got a good man killed. Soljak grabs a phone from Terrell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty miles away - last stop for the #3 trains. Here the subway is elevated. A tower - an old cottage made of wood steel - looks over the station and streets below. Tower c ler MORRISEY (Jamaican, same age as Soljak) is on the pho

dialogues.speaker: MORRISEY
dialogues.text: Mister Soljak. Hear you're call- ing it quits. So where to now? Florida? Gonna visit the Bronx to say goodbye? Or are you too busy with the mayor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak steps onto the platform to take the call.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Hold the jokes. You reported a #3 never got there?

dialogues.speaker: MORRISEY
dialogues.text: The one that left New Lots yard at 5:52, supposed to get in at 7:12 --- (checks his thick paperwork) That one never showed.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What do you mean it never showed?

dialogues.speaker: MORRISEY
dialogues.text: It never came in. But everything’s screwed up here with that schmuck you had on the tracks in Brooklyn. (gets paperwork from an assistant; to Soljak:) Here: I got the #3 that left at 5:40 came in at 7. The 6 a.m. came in at 7:15. Everything else came and went and they should all be back in Brooklyn by now or on their way back here again, but I got nothing on the 5:52 - sure it left the yard this morning?  42.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I called the yard. It left the yard. And the bad news is the operator and conductor are Malik and Rodriquez, the King and Queen of Fuck-ups. Of course they’re not answering their phones --- (to Terrell) Find Malick and Rodriguez. Now. Soljak turns to find: Michelle. She gives Soljak the "com here" finger. Soljak gets off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: We're canceling that thing tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: My thing? No! The shuttle’s con- nected. The Mayor’s shuttle. Food is coming. The balloons are ready. I'll get everything straightened out. The shuttle’s connected and ---

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: And a man got ripped to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: That has nothing to do with us, me. That accident was his mistake. Workers make mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Hear what happened at Whitehall Street? Wait ‘til the Mayor gets off his plane and hears about that. Soljak looks to Terrell: what’s she talking about? Terrel has no idea. MICHELLE MURPHY (CONT’D) I couldn’t begin to explain it, but it’s not good. A Soljak look --- and Terrell’s on the phone to get detai MICHELLE MURPHY (CONT’D) And now I understand a train is “missing”?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: “Missing”? Who said? We’re tracing that unit. Jeez, the rumors ---  43.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Someone named Tupelo’s been calling every city office - “my wife was on that train and now she’s missing.”

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Michelle, on a slow day we get a hundred calls about missing people. And when we start holding trains for investigation, like this, well ---

dialogues.speaker: IN TUNNELS THROUGHOUT BROOKLYN ---
dialogues.text: --- trains filled with passengers sit stalled in darkness

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --- every fifteen minutes we back up nine other trains - so a stalled train means like eight thousand people ---

dialogues.speaker: ON STATION PLATFORMS THROUGHOUT BROOKLYN ---
dialogues.text: --- crowds waiting for trains grow larger --- are gonna be late, lost, or whatever, times every 15 minutes until we get our schedule back---

dialogues.speaker: IN OFFICES, CLASSES, RESTAURANTS, COURTROOMS ---
dialogues.text: --- empty chairs, missing people late for dates --- --- which at this point could be four or five hours --- RANDOM FRIENDS AND BOSSES AND LOVERS are annoyed, indifferent, or worried. Some make calls. INT. DIVISION OFFICE PLATFORM —- DAY

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: --- so we’re gonna get a lot of phone calls from a lot of nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: This nut is Richard Tupelo, an assistant professor of physics at Columbia University. I checked.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: The guy was yelling that he was chasing “Tinkerbell”! So what if he's a teacher? He's a nut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes Bob the Reporter. Michelle lifts her hand: sto She dictates the party line, wants to control this story:

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: A city worker - we’re checking his blood alcohol level - got careless and was hit by a train. That’s worth an inch on page 17 - if you want that exclusive interview.

dialogues.speaker: BOB THE REPORTER
dialogues.text: What about Whitehall Street?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Do you want a stalled train story or do you want the mayor? Bob the Reporter wants the mayor. He backs off. MICHELLE MURPHY (CONT’D) (to Soljak, whisper) I still don't understand how a train disappears.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Stop using that word. All morning we're detouring units, people throw incorrect switches and Brooklyn trains wind up somewhere in Queens or the Bronx - and then the people who screwed up turn off their phones and try to cover their mistakes; it happens. So let’s not create a panic when there’s no reason for panic.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: How many people on an average train?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: On that one we’re talking a #3 at Bergen Street - before rush hour - that’s a 6-car train - maybe 12-15 riders in each car - 90 people.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: That’s a relief: on the day the Mayor’s opening a new subway line only 90 people are missing.  45.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: No: one person - no, one person who says one person is missing. Michelle, we’re in the process of locating our motorman and conductor. They are not our best employees. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Not good enough. You will now take me to the place that shows where all the trains are and I want to talk to those people in that room.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Oh: you mean the NASA room ---?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Is that what they call it?

dialogues.speaker: ANTISEPTIC DETAIL ---
dialogues.text: --- filled with rows of earnest technicians ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: The room with the big computer screen like an air traffic control place, the central command where every one of our 6,200 cars is a blinking light with a number that tells you where every train is at any given moment on our 842 miles of interconnecting lines - so we can simply find the train. Is that where you want me to take you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle Murphy nods: yes! Soljak smiles sourly:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: That room, Michelle, doesn't exist. In the mind of every passenger, every cop, every person like you that room’s in their fantasy im- agination. But we don't have any room like that. We have this ---  46. Points to the crowded, dank room beside them, in a tunnel with a board displaying a localized section of track and uniform little red lights with no markings.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --- and a dozen more just like it. Some even have a big map of the whole subway system. But even there we have no way of knowing which trains those lights repre- sent. We just know that each red light is a train - but which train? That's anyone’s guess.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: (that sinking feeling) There's no master computer?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Well, we sometimes have guys posted in the tunnels with clipboards to mark off the trains as they pass. City budget being what it is we're in the 12th Century down here and that's why we sometimes misplace things. But we always do find them. Besides, I don’t know that there even is a missing train --- Soljak thinks fast, does not want this blown out of proportion, does not want his day ruined:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That guy who fell on the tracks, that teacher - I was with him and he saw someone who was on that train, saw her an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: He did? Well where is he?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (fishes out Tupelo's phone number) I got his number.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: I want to see him. Get him here. Soljak turns to find Terrell. Soljak gives him the number  47.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Find this nut. And Terrell: between Bergen Street and Boro Hall, who's on clipboard?

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: (ashen-faced) We need to get to Whitehall Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noon. Jamal and some friends bounce out of the side exit. Tupelo waits, adrenaline pumping.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: It's Mister Unreal. (pokes him) You real today?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (pushes away Jamal’s hand) Where’s your friend Tinkerbell? Jamal reacts, sees the bruises on Tupelo’s face.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: What she do to you?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We ran into each other this morning - and she almost killed me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Not her. She's into that peace shit.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Didn’t seem so peaceful to me. Look, my wife’s missing and the last person to see her was your friend.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: “Friend”? Who said she’s my ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Tinkerbell’s in trouble. Big trouble. Jamal motions his friends: keep going without me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: What? She steal some spray paint?  48.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: The police want her for attempted murder - attempting to murder me. But I need to ask her some ques-— tions before the cops get to her - and before she disappears.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Like ask her what?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (snaps at him) I’m talking, you’re listening. This is your fault and you’re gonna help me. She knocked me on the tracks. I figured it was an accident, but maybe she followed me ‘cause I “touched” her - in which case I’m blaming you, you’re involved now.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Me!? It was a joke. Leave me out of this.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: She hit me, she jumped on a train - and now that train is missing, and my wife - who was on that train - is gone. But Tinkerbell's not missing - I saw her - and I need to ask her exactly what happened and you are going to help me find her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: But she’s not around today.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Where is she? Where’s she live? Be smart. Make me your friend.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: What do I get out of this? Tupelo stares at Jamal: how do I reach this kid? Then:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I can read you. Okay? I know what you're thinking. So here’s the deal: if I can read your mind you help me. If I can’t --- I give you a hundred bucks.  49.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Wha -? Get away from me.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You scared? Why? If I lose you get a hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Try. Read my mind. Tupelo pulls out a twenty dollar bill, writes something o it, stuffs it in Jamal’s shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Okay, look me in the eye. Pay attention. What’s 5 + 5?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Shit man.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Answer me: what is 5 + 5?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: 8 + 2, c'mon fast.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: 7 + 3? Faster.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Ten!

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Ten.  50.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Ten.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Ten! Ten! Ten!

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Name a vegetable.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Uh, uh --- carrot.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Take that twenty out and see what I wrote on it. Jamal pulls out the bill, unfolds it. It says: CARROT

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Shit! How the hell did you---!!?
Tupelo grabs Jamal by the sleeve and starts walking him.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you after we find her. Keep the twenty. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Controlled chaos. Soljak and cops huddle around the opera of the train hit by the storm of energy. People get first inspectors take statements. TRANSIT OFFICIALS compare not

dialogues.speaker: TRANSIT OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Sixty-five people taken to the hospital, sixty treated here and released, and I guess we’re look- ing at about five hundred lawsuits.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSIT LAWYER
dialogues.text: Subway doors open in a tunnel --- this leads the evening news. When the mayor lands - we’re screwed. ELECTRICAL ENGINEERS climb from the track pit.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ELECTRICAL ENGINEER
dialogues.text: (to Soljak) Every relay’s fried all the way back to Court Street. And get this: there’s a section of rail turned black. What the hell’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I need to take a look at that.

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
