dialogues.text: (tugs at Soljak) They finally sent the tapes over.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What tapes?

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: Bergen Street.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (to the engineer) Gimme a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A surprisingly primitive room at the end of an undergroun platform - tiny lights on a map show a local section of track. Soljak, cops, and TA Officials watch a portable monitor connected to an out-of-date digital video player. ON THE MONITOR (6:20 a.m.) A TRAIN PULLS INTO A STATION - WE SEE: Tupelo and Renee r onto the platform, get on the last car of the train.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Okay, that's Grand Army Plaza.

dialogues.speaker: TA OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Why the hell’s that old car hooked on it? I thought we junked all of those. Soljak says nothing as ON THE MONITOR: The train with Car #8686 at the rear pulls out of the station.

dialogues.speaker: TA TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: Now the next station, Bergen Street. THE IMAGE SWITCHES TO THE BERGEN STREET STATION (6:23 a.m Train pulls into station. Tupelo steps out. Tupelo reacts  52. Renee - starts to get back on. Doors close. He pounds the door. Train moves on. Tupelo left behind. Renee goes to the back window. BANG! --- --- Tupelo is hit, falls into the track pit as Tinkerbell chases the train and leaps on to the last car and the tra disappears into the tunnel. Cops pull Tupelo from the tra

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (to the technician) Go to Atlantic Avenue - next stop. The technician hesitates, looks to the TA officials. Then

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: We don't have cameras there.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER GARRETT
dialogues.text: Only half the stations have cameras.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: No cameras at Atlantic Avenue?

dialogues.speaker: TRANSIT OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Atlantic Avenue with nine connect- ing lines --- and no cameras? Is this possible!? You're getting rid of half my ticket clerks who watch everything before you have cameras in all the stations!?

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: (wants to calm the boss) What's the next station with a camera?

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: DeKalb Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Go to DeKalb - at what time Terrell?

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: Train left Bergen Street at 6:23, should pull into DeKalb at 6:38.  53. MONITOR VIEW: DEKALB STATION - the time code reads 6:36. People begin to crowd onto the platform. At 6:38 - no train. RAPT ATTENTION IN THE CONTROL ROOM as they see the platform get more crowded. On the monitor: 6:39.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: Nothing arrives until 6:52 - and it's a different train.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (controlled fury) Great. Terrific. Fine. So a train leaves Bergen Street and - what? - evaporates? Gets on a boat and goes to the Bahamas? Shut down the whole tunnel from Bergen Street to DeKalb.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSIT OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: There goes our rush hour.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Let ‘em walk. Maybe they'll appre- ciate what we do down here. I’m gonna walk. Yeah. I’m gonna walk that tunnel, personally, and I'm gonna find out what the --- Suddenly: the voice of ---

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Mr. Soljak, may I speak to you alone for a moment? This is not good. They step out of the crowded control ro

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Cancel the party. Early retirement. As of tonight I quit.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: I tried to cancel it, now I can’t. (off Soljak’s reaction) The mayor called from his plane - looking down at America he calls me, and insists on this party --- to show strength and confidence, ‘cause he’s heard your entire goddamn subway’s falling apart!

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: It’s always falling apart  54.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Well fix it before he gets here! (then a strange smirk) Uh, find that man you were looking for? Columbia University? Professor? The science guy?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Not my priority right now.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Make it your priority. Cops were just at his apartment ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Garrett and a DETECTIVE look around the place, se the mirrors, the model car. As they move around the model reflected in the mirrors - the car disappears.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Seems he’s also some kind of magician. And he does have a wife who seems to have vanished. Cops are looking for him now. And something else about him --- The detective breaks through the locked bedroom door. Fli on the light. We don’t see what he sees, but his expressi is raw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle presses Soljak: MICHELLE MURPHY (CONT’D) We might have a psycho on our hands. You said you had his phone number. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three sets of parallel tracks through a dark dripping tun WE HEAR that DEEP BASS NOTE - makes our skin crawl. Switches and light signals in the center track begin to s and strobe. The missing train is here - invisible - pulli energy from the system. WE SEE the GLOW, HEAR the GROWL of a very real oncoming t rounding a curve on the side tracks. NOW WE ARE ---—  55. INSIDE THE MOTORMAN’S COMPARTMENT - MOTORMAN’S POV Easing the throttle to control the speed as he takes the curve - the lives of five hundred passengers in his hand the ribbon of glowing track heading towards a station. He HEARS - above the rattle and noise in his compartment - that DEEP BASS NOTE from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The “phantom” train’s tracks begin to SHUDDER - rails GLO with a surge of energy - the GLOW JUMPING onto the tracks the passing real train - transferring energy - and contro INT. SUBWAY - MOTORMAN’S POV - SPEEDING THROUGH A TUNNEL, It’s as if WE’RE DRIVING THE TRAIN as it enters the stati The platform overcrowded. The motorman plays the brakes - 110 yards to stop - people push close to the edge - from motorman’s POV we see the inherent danger. SUDDENLY --- A LITTLE GIRL DARTS OUT TOWARDS THE EDGE. Motorman presses the brake hard. IT’S LOCKED - won’t move Motorman BLASTS his horn. SOMEONE GRABS THE KID before the train slams her. Brakes engage - the motorman slams the throttle - WHEELS SCREECH stopping the train two cars past the end of the platform. WE SEE THE MOTORMAN’S FACE: He’s freaked. We’re freaked. Now we’re all on edge as ---

dialogues.speaker: THAT STORM OF POWER
dialogues.text: flashes past the train and continues deeper into the tunn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the grip of chaos, crowded - confused people try to he an announcement that hints at the density of action here:

dialogues.speaker: STATION ANNOUNCEMENT
dialogues.text: All D Trains have been taken out of service, transfer to the Q. The 2, 3, 4 and 5 on the lower levels and the M and N will be using the B and R plat- forms and all F, A, and C Trains in both directions have been diverted to the central platform tracks.  56. CLOSE SHOT - A FINGER ---— --- on the large subway wall map traces the route of the the red line - as it moves down from the Bronx and Manhat into Brooklyn until it reaches --- ON THE MAP —- BROOKLYN: THE BORO HALL-ATLANTIC-DEKALB VOR An overlay of 9 stations where every subway line converge orange, red, green, blue, yellow, brown - the entire spec as if laid out by a shattered prism through which every t in the system eventually passes. The finger belongs to --

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: We're here. “The Power Spot” she calls it. C’mon, let’s go --- I want to know about that carrot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jamal leads Tupelo through the multi-level labyrinth o staircases, tunnels, and passageways, the ballet of peopl moving up-down-across-—and-around seems like an M.C. ESCH DRAWING of interlocked motion and connection. ON THE MOVE

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: So how'd you do it?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It was easy.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: If it’s so easy why can’t you read my mind and know where she is right now?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Don’t get cute. That wasn’t the bet, that wasn’t our deal.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: But how’d you do it? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: The minute we find her. They move past a row of subway shops - shoe repair, keys, pizza - a radio blares “Our Lips Are Sealed” - drowned ou by a SUBWAY SCREECH! - and a dark BASS NOTE from some dee subterranean place. Tupelo winces. Jamal keeps them movin

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: So how’d you know she was the one?  Tupelo grabs 57.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Tinkerbell?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: No man, your wife. How’d you know she was the one for you?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I just felt it. I just knew.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: “Just knew” - you got to do better than that, man. Was it what? - her looks? Way she kissed you? Gimme some direction here. Shit, you’d make some lousy father. Jamal, slams him into the wall. Jamal reacts - innocent - it was a joke. Tupelo’s face: twisted. Tupelo eases Tupelo nods,

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chill man. Be the grown-up. What? off. Then calmly gives the answer:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It was the way she looked, and the way she looked at me, and the way she would say things, and what things bothered her, and what things didn’t bother her, and --- she was great to kiss and we were just - we were a great team.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: “Were,” “was,” “used to,” what's all the past tense? You over it?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We’ve got some problems now. But you don’t quit on someone cause you have problems. You try to fix things, try to get things right again. You try to get things back.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Hope it works out. For real. smiles at this kid, then something catches his eye on the wall just beyond Jamal’s shoulder ---  58. THE NYC SUBWAY WALL MAP - CLOSE SHOT —- DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN --- where all the subway lines converge into what LOOKS LIKE A HOPELESSLY KNOTTED WEB OF MULTI-COLORED STRINGS.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO SEES
dialogues.text: some pattern in the map, some pattern in those strings converging in Brooklyn, some pattern he’s trying to read, formulate, comprehend. He mutters:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Never saw it like this. This looks --- it’s just like a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He digs into his pocket, finds the card Soljak gave him, to find a weak cell phone signal. Bangs out Soljak’s numb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak on the street, moving, takes the staticky call.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo covers his ear, cups the cell phone:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: The guy who got pushed on the tracks. Find that train yet? INTERCUT STREET AND SUBWAY -— --- both noisy as hell ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: No. You got it?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: What kind of stupid question is that? You think I ---? So you can’t find it, huh? Well, I’m looking at a map here ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Where are you Mr. Tupelo?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Do you know what a Moebius Strip is? Tell me about this morning.  59.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: First you tell me: where are you? INT. ATLANTIC STREET STATION —- DAY Tupelo senses trouble. Ends the call. Stares at the map o knotted lines in Brooklyn. Jamal grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: This ain't the art museum. You want Tinkerbell? Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak pushes his way downstairs to the station and tunne the train disappeared. As transit workers put up barriers

dialogues.speaker: STATION ANNOUNCEMENT
dialogues.text: This station has been closed. We apologize for the inconvenience. --- a throng of angry commuters exits upstairs - some peo bark, others make it easy - intertwined human behavior - Soljak is not part of this people-world and we realize, e in the crowd, how deeply alone he is. A transit worker we ing safety gear, with clipboard (CLIPBOARD MAN), meets hi

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD MAN
dialogues.text: Ever wonder where they’re all going?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: No. I’m just supposed to get them there. Let’s do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak and Clipboard Man - reflective vests, flashlights walk the dark one-track tunnel. If a train comes, no esca But this track is shut. We hope. A half-mile of signal li warn: STOP. A dark world of strange noises, trash, and ra

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: A train entered this tunnel. No evidence it came out. Magic, huh? Clipboard Man tests a smile - sees that Soljak is not jok

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD MAN
dialogues.text: There are no switches until the next stop, sir. Train goes in here, only thing that could happen is ---  60.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD MAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Each step deeper into the tunnel echoes louder. Now betwe the tracks: burnt rats. Clipboard Man looks back towards lights of Bergen Street Station - a quarter mile away. It quarter mile further to Atlantic Avenue Station. They’re the middle. Clipboard Man is already jittery, then:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD MAN
dialogues.text: (wants to run away) You hear something?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Give me your light. Soljak shines both lights on the rails. A section of rail a dense jet black.

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD MAN
dialogues.text: Never seen that before. You? Soljak has - but doesn’t answer. He moves closer to the blackened rail. Careful. Bends to touch it, wipes the soot - the steel itself has turned bl CLIPBOARD MAN (CONT’D) What’s it mean? Soljak finger to lips: shh. A throb in the tunnel. Tensio CLIPBOARD MAN (CONT’D) (voice shaky) Uh, sir --- Chief --- over there--- Soljak aims the lights further down the track.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Don’t move. Soljak steps forward. Stops. Sees:  61. TINKERBELL’S BACKPACK in the muck between the tracks. Covered with scribbled no Looks like a bomb.

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD MAN
dialogues.text: (backing away) Don’t touch it. Could be ---. Soljak knows it means something, but not a bomb. Still:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Slap yourself and calm down. We have to follow protocol - call the cops and the FBI. You’re in charge here now.

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD MAN
dialogues.text: Me? What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Cancel a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lowest level. Jamal and Tupelo. Alone. Signs: IF YOU SEE SOMETHING SAY SOMETHING. There are rusted doors on the platform wall, so rusted you'd pass them without noticing But one is freshly spray-painted yellow.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: That's her. Jamal goes to the yellow-sprayed lock. Has a key.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Where'd you get that?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: I look out for her sometimes. The lock CLICKS. Jamal pulls the creaky door open. It's a dark, drippy, rust-streaked entrance to a chilly underwor that leads down to a humming realm beneath the subway.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She says this leads to hell. Still want to find your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bomb squad vans SCREAM and PUSH through the traffic. Cops transit workers evacuate the stations. News and police he  62. copters overhead. Chaos verging on panic. And now it’s staring to RAIN. CAMERA FINDS: Soljak - alone in the crow - keeping something to himself.

dialogues.speaker: TV NEWSWOMAN
dialogues.text: The discovery of a suspicious device on the tracks has shut down all subway lines in Brooklyn. Police cannot say when the stations will be re-opened, but investigators-—-- Nothing Soljak can do here - gets in a waiting car driven Terrell. Terrell puts a red light on top and kicks the si INT. PHYSICS LAB —- COLUMBIA UNIVERSTIY, MANHATTAN - DAY OUTSIDE THE WINDOW: SIRENS SCREAM through traffic. INSIDE Soljak and Terrell with department head PROFESSOR WILKIE. Formulas cover the walls. Soljak is shocked as he repeats what Wilkie just said:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: You mean we've been trying to find this guy and now you tell me he’s not some kind of professor here?

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: Not anymore. We lost “Artie.” Bril- liant student, but ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Artie? I’m looking for Richard Tupelo. Who’s “Artie’?

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: That’s what we called him: “R-T” - Richard Tupelo - his initials.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (to Terrell) Who said he was a teacher here?

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: Michelle Murphy. Soljak motions Terrell: we’re in the wrong place.

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: He once taught here. I understand he still is a teacher - a substi- tute teacher, in The Bronx --- Substitute teacher? It’s migraine time for Soljak.  63.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Look, we’ve got a train missing, he may be involved, and we need to find him. Where do we look?

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: Artie’s had a tough run, but I can’t imagine ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: “Tough run” - what’s that mean?

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: He lost a baby - staph infection - no one’s fault, she went so quick, it just happened --- INT. TUPELO AND RENEE’S APARTMENT - EARLIER TODAY The cops push into the locked bedroom --- baby clothes, a bassinet, changing table, toys and dolls - all tossed into an angry, ugly pile in the middle of the floor

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --- and I hear his marriage ---.

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: And he was one of my brightest. Sadly what he chose to work on was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I’m almost afraid to ask. Wilkie explains by drawing a single line across a chalkbo

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: This is the electromagnetic spectrum: this area - radio waves, radar, infra- red, X-rays, gamma rays - nothing we can see --- only this very small part of the wave band, here, in the middle, just this fraction of the spectrum is what we can see with our eyes - but all the rest, even if we can’t see it - it all exists. But we only see this tiny piece of our world.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Yeah I get it. I work with engineers. I’m not an idiot. So what?  64.

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: The invisible spectrum. Very exciting field. Only he took things too far. Soljak: which means? Wilkie makes a dot far to the right:

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Out here are electromagnetic waves with stupendously high frequencies. He felt, and taught, that out here the speed of light is not absolute, that pulses of energy could travel faster than light. I warned him it was laughable, but he persisted. I had to ask him to leave. The (O.S.) RUMBLE of the subway that runs beneath the university. That sound shakes us up. Now it also shakes up Soljak. He pulls Terrell to the exit ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Thanks for the class.

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: Of course now it seems he was right.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE
dialogues.text: We’re only just developing the tools to prove it but now we know that a pulse of light shot into a strand of optical fiber can depart before it even enters, indeed faster than the speed of light - it’s now part of our science. I’ve always wanted to apologize to “R-T” --- Soljak squints, Wilkie presses on:

dialogues.speaker: WILKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --- you see, he knew it: if anything is faster than light, imagine the possibilities of perception, dimen- sions, and what might be happening, right now, all around us and right beneath our feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dripping with stalagmites and laced with a spiderweb of s  65. zling, hissing wires covered with smoking wet rags, walls crawling with bugs, sounds of scurrying rats as Tupelo an Jamal make their way down the rotted staircase, emerging INT. THE OLD MYRTLE STREET STATION —- BROOKLYN A dark, haunted place with it’s signs fallen down, pothol on the platform, and cracked tiles on the walls - one of the dozen gloomy, abandoned New York subway stations.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Myrtle Street. Damn - this was a stop when I was a kid. Rain drizzles down from the track ceiling. Lights flicker The effect is a TWINKLING STROBE-EFFECT that plays with o sense of depth, space, and reality. As Tupelo’s eyes focu they come to rest on an old rusted plaque on the wall:

dialogues.speaker: THE SUP RVISOR FOR THIS STATION IS CRYTHEN BELL
dialogues.text: TUPELO (CONT’D) (remembers ---) “Cry Then Bell” --- that was one of her notes. She lives here?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Hides out from the world.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: But then she goes to school?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Hot meals for free. Guess she likes other kids. But this is her place.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Right there --- Tupelo’s breath catches. Twenty steps away a pile of rags cardboard on a broken subway bench camouflages a fragile human: Tinkerbell. Jamal repeats what Tupelo sneered at h

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thing you need to learn is: “as tough as you think your life is, for someone else it's even worse.”  66.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (chastened) She have any family?

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Oh, she has people --- (shakes his head, disgust) That’s why she’s down here.

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL WHISPERS
dialogues.text: -- her fury and bravado gone - a frightened kid:

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Help me. Tupelo kneels beside her.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I want to. But first I need you to help me. She tries to make herself smaller. Covering the grimy wal behind her she’s created a collage of old and new found expressions: WHO WILL BE MISS SUBWAYS? - IF YOU SEE SOME- THING SAY SOMETHING - HANDS OFF UNLESS AUTHORIZED - and: “8686” - stuck to the wall with tape and gum. TUPELO (CONT’D) “WHO WILL BE MISS SUBWAYS”? --- that’s from like fifty years ago, where did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Sometimes my head feels sick and I see things. But this morning, it was the worst --- like what you said: close off a room and inside, no one’s looking, it’s all crazy, right? Well sometimes, what you said no one can see - well, some- times, I can.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (this is huge for him) You can? Really? What’s it like? She looks to Jamal - can I trust him? Jamal nods.

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Everything moving real fast, but soft, like clouds of color, like (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the whole world is melting - then it goes away. When I tell people about it they all wanna lock me up, they think I’m crazy. Am I? Tupelo tests touching her shoulder. She doesn’t pull away but her hands are clutched tightly inside her coat. Gentl

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: What you see - don’t be scared of it. It’s a gift, a wonderful power that I think we’re all born with and then we forget: the world as it is - an accurate vision of light and form and color. It’s what babies see when they first open their eyes - before they’re trained to just see the world as this --- He motions to the world around them: filth, grease, darkn

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did you see this morning? Her voice is even, soft, but her eyes are pure terror:

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: I was running, they were chasing me, so I jumped ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Tinkerbell grips the greasy, swinging, clattering guar chains and pulls herself up onto the swaying foot plate - grime and dust swirling ---

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I saw this lady’s face, she looked like she hated me --- Renee is pressed to the window, terror, fury ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That was my wife, she’d just seen you push me onto the tracks. Renee starts banging on the window of the locked rear doo all the anger and sadness and disappointments and pain of  68. her life now focused on Tinkerbell ---

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --- but then she looked at me --- Renee - her eyes locked on Tinkerbell - sees a frightened teenager - and Renee’s face takes on an almost-angelic gl --- like she cared about me --- Renee’s fists open, her palms to the window, trying to co this frightened child. A POWERFUL MOMENT: Renee as streng hope, promise, and pure love - the Renee that Tupelo love

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --- but behind her --- WE SEE: THE ONCOMING STORM. Renee is framed in its halo, just as it reaches her ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tinkerbell falls silent. Does not want to remember. Tupel touches her cheek. She continues:

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: I don’t know the words - it was coming right at me and then the train was gone and the lady was gone and just before it got to me I just let go and I fell on the tracks and --- (crying like a little kid) I hurt myself. Tupelo puts his arms around her as if she were his own ch He moves the rags from her clasped hands. Her palms and w are a HORRIBLE STEW OF BRUISES, CUTS, FILTH, WET AND DRY from when she fell.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Aw --- Tink ---. Tupelo hugs her closer - father of the year.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We need to get you cleaned and fixed.

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: No. No doctors.  Jamal starts She motions: platform, ON 69.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You will lose your hands.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: (first time: fear) You got to let him help. He’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: But it’s all gone. I thought it was just those things I see but then people were looking for it and they said the train was gone so it really did happen, right?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Yes. It did. The train disappeared. to joke, sees Tupelo is serious.

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: I think I know why it happened.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: We got to get her to a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: That’1l be your job. I’11 tell you who to take her to. After. (to Tinkerbell) What made it happen?

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: That lady who didn’t hate me --- promise me you’1ll save her.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: That’s why I’m here. follow me. She leads them towards the end of the THE OLD SUBWAY BENCH we see a mark of vandalism on the wood - faded carved initials: “RT”.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE END OF THE PLATFORM
dialogues.text: TinkerBell pulls open a sheet of corrugated tin that lead THE “BENCH-WALL” — - a narrow ledge right above the tracks that hugs the wal tunnels and lead to secret rooms and stairways to even de depths. As they follow TinkerBell along the slippery ledg seems they’re alone in the center of the earth. Then they  70.

dialogues.speaker: A STRANGE CHORUS OF CHIRPING -
dialogues.text: Tupelo: Huh? He peers into a tiny portal, sees a hidden r that sounds like IT’S FILLED WITH DERANGED CRICKETS. This A RELAY ROOM --— --- a tarp-covered, rag-filled, spiderweb of wires that h a crucial part of the subway’s nervous system, yet also o of the most ancient - “relays” are small switches flickin and off, a technology in use since the subway opened in 1 Tinkerbell tries to explain:

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Whenever trains go by they always start clicking back and forth ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPLEO
dialogues.text: Some kind of electromagnets. (sees the cloth-covered wires leading out of the room) Must be connected to the tracks some- where, and when a train passes --- (figures) It shorts the circuit. Which would let the system know a train is there --- or not. (astonished: ) Those aren’t even plastic, they’re Bakelite, from the 30’s, and all those wires - all wrapped in cloth! Jeez, pure entropy.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: What’s that mean? Tupelo wants to keep moving, no time to explain. Jamal ho him, always wants answers. So:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TUPELO AND RENEE - pressed together in a crowded, moving, subway car - they hold each other, the moment they were most in love ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It means that anything complex and interconnected --- CAMERA EDGES BACK: RENEE IS PREGNANT - this is a happier for them, a time of hope and promise, THEY SEEM TO GLOW -  71. TUPELO (V.O.) (CONT’D) --- unless you keep it right --- FLASHBACK: TUPELO AND RENEE KISS. TUPELO (CONT’D) Will always break down.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN SWEEPS PAST OUR VIEW
dialogues.text: EACH OTHER'S LOVE, become a smear of steel, flesh, and li

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And when it does start breaking down --- CLOSE SHOT - THE TRAIN’S UNDERBELLY AND THE TRACKS BLUE SPARKS as the speeding train’s “shoes” scrape the th rail - picking up the current that powers the train. TUPELO (V.O.) (CONT’D) --- you might never know how the problems got started. INSTANTLY WE ARE TRANSPORTED --—— --- into a small, hyper-clean UNREAL white room with one simple relay switch atop a metal table. TUPELO (V.O.) (CONT’D) Like: if this room were empty, any- thing changes - like a piece of paper near a wire - you'd see it. A crumbled piece of paper NOW APPEARS --- too close to an exposed wire - ready to spark. Easy to see. Easy to fix. TUPELO (V.O.) (CONT’D) But if that same room is ---

dialogues.speaker: FILTHY RELAY ROOM ---
dialogues.text: TUPELO (V.O.) (CONT’D) --- a maze of distractions crowded with rags and wires - with water dripping and sparks flying - you'd never see the trouble --- --- that shred of paper about to catch fire can no longer  72. even be seen.

dialogues.speaker: NEW YORK CITY
dialogues.text: Thousands of streets and buildings, bridges and highways moving ten million people - an organism of complex and infinite connections, now falling into chaos and crisis - TUPELO (V.O.) (CONT’D) --- and when all those little troubles and problems cause the whole system to fail - no one would ever know why. THE HELICOPTER - “CITY OF NEW YORK” LOGO --- - lands. Michelle anxiously waits on the helipad tarmac t greet --- THE MAYOR. WE RETURN TO: INT. THE DEPTHS OF THE SUBWAY SYSTEM — Tupelo, Tinkerbell, and Jamal stand on the slippery bench above the tracks, peer into the mess that is Relay Room 2

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: How many rooms like this?

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Whole city. In all the tunnels. Everywhere. C’mere, gets worse --- She motions to the slimiest, rustiest, most corroded meta door seen yet - no doubt the passage to some even more ho dungeon-like mystery. Tupelo takes a deep breath, then no open it. She pushes open the filthy portal ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --- what he sees takes his breath away. HE SEES:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pure white, antiseptically clean, shining SUBWAY STATIO SOMETHING WE NEVER EVEN IMAGINED COULD EXIST --- like a s station with electronic signs and shiny sets of track, ev the tunnels leading in and out of this station are spotle It’s like some imaginary wonder-world, but this place is

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: (gives her the creeps) They just made it. For the O Line. FROM SOMEWHERE FAR ABOVE they can hear/feel the rumblings  73. trains, water mains, power lines, and a city of ten milli people - but down here it’s like a beautiful, lifeless to TINKERBELL (CONT’D) Like a year ago they started fixing this place up --- and that’s when the crazy things started to happen. Tupelo goes to a backlit 8ft-high subway map set in the w

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Where are we now?

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Right here --- She points to that “Power Spot” confluence of connections Brooklyn, but now there’s a new marking on this map: THE “O LINE SHUTTLE,” a silver line that sweeps through Brooklyn’s knot of mult colored transit lines and continues through to Queens, Th Bronx, Manhattan, and back to Brooklyn --- tying all the strands of the system together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is mystified, incredulous, half elated, half horrified

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: This is so sick.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL AND TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: What!? Tupelo points to the subway map on the wall:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You see this new line? You see what happens here? They have no idea, but --- I was right - it’s real --- they've created a Moebius Strip!

dialogues.speaker: B-RING
dialogues.text: They STARTLE --- huh? - it’s Tupelo’s cell phone. TUPELO (CONT’D) This works ---? We’re five levels down into bedrock. How’s this ---?  74.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Look: cell phone boosters built right into the walls. Cool. Tupelo looks at his ringing phone:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: 27 missed calls and messages --- (he answers the incoming call) Hello --- ? Tupelo has to move the phone from his ear ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (ON THE PHONE, BELLOWING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell you been!?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Ah, my new friend.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: So Tupelo, this some kind of prank?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Screw you, my wife’s on that train.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Tell me this is a joke. Some magic shit - smoke and mirrors.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (ON THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Don’t hang up! --- EXT. ON THE STREET —- DAY

dialogues.speaker: GRIDLOCK, SIRENS, CROWDS, COPS, BOMB SQUAD, NEWS, FBI, HE
dialogues.text: COPTERS OVERHEAD, - Soljak - pacing, on the phone - is watching the world as he and we know it falls apart.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Are you playing games with me?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: What happened at 6:23 this morning that never happened before?  75.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: 6:23 ---? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: In the Myrtle Street Station.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: The old station?!

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: No. The new station.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: The shuttle? You can’t be in that station. It’s all locked up.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: And yet, here I am. What happened today at 6:23 a.m?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What do you care? What’s that got to do with ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Hey Pal, you wouldn’t be calling me unless you couldn’t call anyone else. You know something’s wrong. What happened this morning at 6:23?!

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: The shuttle happened. We finally connected the last tracks of the shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo, speaking to Soljak, traces the shuttle line on th

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: And at that moment every subway line in the city was turned into one giant endless loop?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Yeah. 6:23. First time ever. What’s that got to do with the Number 3 going AWOL?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Maybe everything. Soljak, is that train really missing?  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tightly-wound Soljak responds quietly:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: We’ve combed every inch of track in the city --- (hates to admit:) Yes. It’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT THE NEW STATION
dialogues.text: Tupelo’s eyes focus on the ominously-glowing subway map, the Power Spot in Brooklyn where all the lines converge.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Then every train is in danger now. And the one that’s missing --- if you want it back then get down here. Alone. No cops. Got that? Get down here. And I'll find it. Tupelo disconnects. To Jamal: TUPELO (CONT’D) Take her to Brooklyn Hospital. Go up to the fifth floor, find Nurse Judy, and tell them Tinkerbell is Renee’s niece.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Who’s Renee?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: My wife. She’s a nurse there and they’1l do anything for her. (to Tinkerbell) She was the lady on the train.

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Do I have to be her niece? Can I be her kid? Can she be my mother?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: She’s not ready for that.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Force that train back to where it escaped from, even if I have to shut down the whole city.  77.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: They won’t let you do that.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: They'll have to. Now get her to the doctor, get out of here! Jamal pulls Tupelo aside, concerned, whispers:

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: If the cops grab Tink’ --- gimme your phone number. Tupelo scribbles the number --- pushes Jamal to go. Jamal Tinkerbell head towards the secret exit. Tupelo glances o more at the map and its jumble of knotted lines in Brookl

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Wait! Tinker--- “Teena” - right? -- - all those little papers you cut up and write on --- you got a piece of paper for me? She nods, finds in her pocket a sheet of paper. TUPELO (CONT’D) And a scissors.

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Scissors? No - I got this --- A razor.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Fine. And some tape. And a pen!

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: You gonna get your train back with a razor blade, paper and a pen? Tinerbell has tape and a marker. Tupelo kisses her forehe

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Good kid. Both of you. Now get to the hospital. Move! Jamal won't move:

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: How'd you know I'd say “carrot”?  78.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It was just a trick. Dumb trick. Get going.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: But how’d you do it? You said you'd tell me.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (exasperated, but has to tell him: ) Ask anyone a series of fast simple questions - 2+8, 3+7, 5+5, 6+4 - that stops their thinking - then ask them to name a vegetable. Most people will say “carrot.” It’s a fact. Now get out of here. Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TV NEWS REPORTER giving her LIVE REPORT stands in front crowds, cops, and Bomb Squad vans.

dialogues.speaker: NEW REPORTER
dialogues.text: A child’s backpack on the tracks was all it took to shut down the subway at rush hour. But in today’s world most would agree it’s better to be safe than sorry. The good news: all subway lines are again in operation. Still, with the system just getting back underway, expect delays that will inconvenience millions of New Yorkers for several more hours. Better cancel those dinner plans - everyone is going to be late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leaving Transit Authority HQ in a car driven by Terrell, instantly stuck in traffic between buses, news vans, and sea of pedestrians. IN THE CAR: Soljak looks out at his world in collapse. Terrell feeds Soljak even more problem

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: She keeps calling: she’s with the mayor and she’s looking for you and she’s really pissed.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Damn this traffic! Do something! Soljak, frustrated, bolts OUT OF THE CAR.  79.

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: No Chief. Don’t. Don’t leave me! Soljak hurries to a subway entrance - but someone grabs h

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Answer your phone when I call you! The mayor will be at this new City Hall Station of yours in 20 minutes. Be there to meet him: 6 p.m. He will speak to the press about im- proved safety - the shuttle will be his example. There will be no discussion of missing trains. Under- stand? And put on a clean shirt. And I assume you found that train?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I’m on my way to get it right now. Soljak dashes down into the subway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak has commandeered a specialized, hot-yellow, eight- Vacuum Car - a futuristic-looking machine that cleans the tracks of the subway and the only thing now running on th new shuttle line. Its powerful overhead beams illuminate rails and tunnel ahead. From the wide front window it’s a almost-magical view of the underworld of the city.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (to the Vac-Car operator) Anything special to running it? The OPERATOR - it’s a woman - shrugs: not really.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wanna let me try? I used to do this. And today might be my last day down here.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR
dialogues.text: (knows she shouldn't, but) Take the controls. The operator slides out of her seat and lets Soljak take - Soljak like a kid with a new set of toy trains. He give the Vac-Car some power - it hums down the track.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Nothing special - just the best job in the world.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo sits on a shiny plastic bench cutting a 2-inch wid 10-inch long strip of paper. A RUMBLE from far down the tunnel. He tenses - a powerful beam of light washes the station. And then it arrives, the strangest looking machi he’s ever seen. Soljak steps out onto the platform, the Vacuum-Car continues on. Soljak appraises Tupelo ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Substitute teacher. Magician. And now: cutting paper dolls. (can’t believe this) I’m in your hands.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You ever hear of a Moebius Strip? Soljak squints. Tupelo shows him the strip of paper. Soun like a magician:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Two sides, right? If I make it into a loop I have an outside and an inside. But, if instead of attaching the ends as a loop I put a twist in the strip, and then attach the ends, what we’ve got is what’s called --- He twists the strip of paper and attaches the opposite en seals them with the tape --- TUPELO (CONT’D) A Moebius Strip --- Looks like a twisted figure eight.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Yeah --- and?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Now, if I take this marker and draw a line down the middle of the strip, look what happens --- Tupelo draws a line down the length of the twisted paper coil; as he follows the architecture of the coil the line  81. comes back to where it started having inscribed both side of the strip. Soljak takes Sokjak grabs TUPELO (CONT’D) I never lifted the pen. So, we had a strip of paper with two sides that now has only one side. Right? So what happened to the other side? Don’t guess. As simple as it seems, this is a profound mystery. You see, when any system makes more and more connections to other parts of itself the connectivity of that system increases in an exponential fashion - in the case of the subway forming a knot of staggering proportions. the seemingly simple moebius from Tupelo.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: There were two sides. Now there’s one side. I'll play: where’s the other side?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Inside. I know that’s hard to imagine. And by “inside” I also mean “outside.”

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: “inside, outside” - I don’t have time for bullshit now --- (crunches the moebius) That train went missing and my system fell apart. Where’s my train? - and I want a nuts-and-bolts answer.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I’m afraid there’s only one answer: your train, with my wife, has slip- ped into a parallel dimension. Tupelo and slams him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: A para---!!? That’s why you brought me here!? Are you---!? You motherf---!

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (cool as ice) Used to be just theory for me, but now I know it’s real.  82.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What's real!?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: The world unseen. SOUNDS GRUMBLE, PILLARS RATTLE - a steady throb of tensio TUPELO (CONT’D) It was something I tried to convince myself of, it helped me imagine the work I was doing, helped me imagine that my kid ---, I tried to convince my wife of it, that there was a world of beauty and amazement right beyond our reach, but that only screwed things up more. But now --- (drags Soljak to ---) Look at your map, your subway is a 842 mile knot of amazing topological complexity, but now adding the shuttle line makes it even more complex - and the situation is now of an order so high that I suspect the connectivity - the properties of all the connections in the New York Subway System - has now become infinite. Can you imagine the properties of an infinite network? (off Soljak’s look) I can’t either. But the train is no longer in the realm of “where,” the whole System is now without a real “whereness,” and your new shuttle has caused the #3 train from Brook- lyn to jump into another dimension.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Fuck You.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t be here unless you knew something was wrong - something way wrong that you can’t explain. Well guess what: that kid who grabbed onto the back of that train - she actually saw it disappear. Now look at this --- Tupelo starts cutting length-wise through the crunched-by Soljak-but-not-broken moebius strip:  83. TUPELO (CONT’D) Now it really gets weird, watch: when I cut this again --- As he makes the final cut ---

dialogues.speaker: LIKE A MAGIC TRICK
dialogues.text: The Moebius strip suddenly snaps itself into two separate moebius strips tied together in a knot! Huh? Soljak react So do we. (NOTE: this actually happens) TUPELO (CONT’D) C’mere, you need to see this --- Tupelo holds the “Moebius Knot” up against THE WALL-SIZED

dialogues.speaker: SUBWAY MAP. CAMERA MOVES IN
dialogues.text: THE MOEBIUS KNOT ---— --- IS A PERFECT MATCH WITH THE “POWER SPOT” JUMBLE OF SU

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What the hell ---!???

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Yeah: “what the hell.” What time did you connect the shuttle tracks to the rest of the system?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: You know what time I connected it.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: When you connected the shuttle tracks this morning you created this. Now I know this map is only an approximation of the system, but the actual connect- ions are even more complex. I got off at Bergen Street. The train continued but never made it to its next stop, but it did enter this newly created moebius knot and moved into a non- spatial plane. It continues to draw power from the System - you know that - so it’s got to be somewhere --- but it’s somewhere we can’t see. Soljak seems ready to punch Tupelo. Tupelo stands his gro  84. TUPELO (CONT’D) Six hundred years ago people weren’t morons - look what they built, the art they created, the cities - all these genius people - and yet for them the world was flat, and the earth was the center of the universe --- (pure energy) ---and then, suddenly, they were totally mind-fucked - suddenly the world was round - round! - and we weren’t the center of existence but one little speck at the edge of space - and then, when the microscope was invented, whoa! - suddenly there’s a whole other world --- of tiny little creatures - living inside our bodies! And so, imagine the future, people in touch with sounds and ideas, waves and currents and signals we can’t fathom - yet. ‘Cause reality itself doesn’t change but the reality in our minds always changes. So what the future will know, it won’t be just this. So are there other dimensions surrounding us, dimensions of time and space that fill in the gaps we can’t explain? Yes. I believe that. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: It can’t be. I gave my life to this machine. Nuts and bolts. “For every action there’s a reaction.” That’s how the world works. Not---.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Then why are you here? Soljak tries to make the words to answer. Can’t. Tupelo moves in close:

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it? I see it in your eyes. You know something. One long moment. Soljak turns away --- mutters. TUPELO (CONT’D) I didn’t hear you. What did you say?  85. Almost a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: That blackened track, missing train --- (beat) It's happened before.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (now he grabs Soljak) What!? It’s happened before!???

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Maybe a year ago, three in the morning, for a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We were testing the current in the shuttle tunnel, no tracks yet, just the power grid, when an F-Train going through Rutgers Tunnel - it’s marker light goes off, then the light comes back on. So who cares, right? Couple a seconds. Coulda been a short circuit. But when the motorman pulls in he says some crazy shit happened - blames the conductor - conductor also says something weird happened - says the motorman must have blacked out at the con- trols - so now they start throwing punches at each other so we follow up: train’s fine, the signals are fine, but the track turned black where that train went off the board. But no one wants to get written up and it’s four in the morning - train was full of drunks, so nobody thinks about this shit - they just want to get home. But I think about it. Then I forget about it. Until now. Tupelo is astonished, elated - and terrified. His theory: true. Soljak: more frightened, more confused.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But why then, if the tracks did this ---  86.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Simple terms: trigger a nuclear reaction, before you get to criti- cal mass you get smaller reactions - that’s why that circuit test you ran only caused that blip, but now, with the tracks ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Then how come every train in the system hasn’t --- how come there aren’t 10, 20, 100 trains missing?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: There must be an exclusion princi- ple operating, such that only one train at a time can occupy the non-spatial network and --- Soljak’s heard enough, gets out his phone, starts a call

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I’m getting a railer team down here, we’ll disconnect a stretch of track, that’1l break your Moebius thing and - POOF! --- we'll get that train back.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (grabs the phone away) No! No! You can’t do that!

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What!? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: The relevant non-spatial property is derived from the shuttle line, but now it belongs to the whole System!

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: In English!

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: If anything changes now, we'll lose that train forever. If you cut the knot --- Tupelo tears one piece of his paper moebius --- and the k  87. instantly collapses into two separate tangled strands. TUPELO (CONT’D) ---you can’t put it back together. The System has to stay the same until we bring back that train! SUDDENLY a pressure in the air, a sizzle of electricity. hairs on their arms begin to rise. Something about to hap Then they hear FROM DOWN IN THE TUNNEL A DEEP RUMBLE, the

dialogues.speaker: HORN BLAST YOU CAN FEEL IN YOUR HEART. A FLASH OF SEARING
dialogues.text: LIGHT, and then ---

dialogues.speaker: A SPIFFY NEW SHUTTLE SUBWAY TRAIN -
dialogues.text: all shiny silver, empty, clean - and real - glides throug the station. Tupelo has never seen a subway train like th Like a mirage. But it’s real. From Soljak: a sad laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: My life’s work.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It’s running already?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Special train.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: To where?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: City Hall. I’m supposed to be there - they were giving me a medal, front page news, a nice party.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You should be there: friends, family.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: This is my family. There it goes. Soljak watches the train disappear into the darkness. Tup sees that Soljak’s cheeks are flushed, his eyes are red.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: You gotta have someone.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: I gave up on that a long time ago. (beat) Hope you got a plan.  88.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We need to propel that missing train back to where it escaped from and trap it--- (goes to the map) It’s living off the power from the rails, right? So by shutting down its power starting up here - moving from the Bronx down to Brooklyn, Queens to Brooklyn, pushing north from Coney Island, Bay Ridge and Rockaway - by cut- ting the power grid section-by- section we can chase it, corner it, and ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: That’s your plan? With the mayor back in town reassuring everyone that everything's perfectly normal?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We'll have to, and then we’1l direct all that energy into Bergen Street Station to shock our train back into the space we inhabit - it was shocked out, we’1ll need to shock it back in.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: You want me to tell the mayor I’m shutting down New York “because a subway train’s in another dimen- sion”!? They’1l put me away.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: But we have to do it.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (no good - final) Sorry, pal. No. Can’t. If that’s the only way, we’re both screwed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Judy treats the cuts and lacerations on Tinkerbell’ hands, wrists, and knees. All around them children are cr - as if they have a special sense that something profound in the air. Jamal, watching Tinkerbell, concern. He holds Tupelo’s scribbled phone number, comments:  89.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Poor man. Lost a baby, now his old lady is gone --- poor Professor What-The-Hell’s-His-Name. He said he was gonna shut down the whole city to catch his train. They’re never gonna let him do that. Nurse Carla passes Jamal, growls at him:

dialogues.speaker: NURSE CARLA
dialogues.text: How'd you know I'd say “carrot”? Nurse Judy is attending to Tinkerbell:

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: This is going to hurt --- Nurse Judy puts a wash of antiseptic on Tinkerbell palm -

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: Ouch. A SECOND NURSE gives Tinkerbell a tetanus shot --- TINKERBELL (CONT’D) Ouch! A THIRD NURSE plucks a steel splinter from Tinkerbell’s k Should be “ouch” --- but this time Tinkerbell does not re She just re-counts each hit of pain: TINKERBELL (CONT’D) One --- two --- three --- Suddenly she jumps to her feet: TINKERBELL (CONT’D) I know how to do it!

dialogues.speaker: AT THE NURSES STATION
dialogues.text: Tinkerbell grabs the number from Jamal, pushes aside nurs grabs a phone, calls - Tupelo answers. Tinkerbell screech TINKERBELL (CONT’D) You don’t have to shut down the whole city! I see it how - when there’s a fire in a tunnel the trains all keep running. They keep running ‘cause it’s three different powers down there!  90. Jamal holds back all the nurses:

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: Let her do her thing. They’re gonna put her in a genius museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo and Soljak listen to the breathless intensity pour out of the cell phone:

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One’s the city electric. One’s all the signals and lights down there. And then there’s the train power! You can just shut down the tracks!

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Is she right?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (realizes: ) Of course - split system, same since 1904 - every train pulls power from the third rail - DC current, s’got nothing to do with the city grid. (very impressed) Who you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: jumping onto the nurses’ desk, yelling into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: TINKERBELL
dialogues.text: So if you cut the train power the stations would still be lit, the city’1l still be lit, but all the trains will stop! And then you can crash the system! Do it! Do it!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE JUDY
dialogues.text: Somebody call Security!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak to Tupelo racing up the escalator to the street.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: How do we explain this to people?  gl.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: We don’t. We can’t. We’ve got to bring it back, you and me, now. Before anything changes! We’ll do it, and no one on the street will even know it happened.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: How long will it take?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: 30 - 45 - 60, tops. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: An hour? Even a half hour? You kidding? At rush hour?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Who said a half hour!? --- 30, 45 seconds! - we’re dealing with the speed of light!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TINKERBELL AND JAMAL --- rushing through the hospital lobby down into the subway entrance just outside the door

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL
dialogues.text: I do not want to miss this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo and Soljak muscle through the rush hour crowd, Sol barking into his phone:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Morrissey! This is what I need from you ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrissey (Soljak’s friend, the Jamaican dispatcher at th elevated tower in The Bronx), reacts:

dialogues.speaker: MORRISSEY
dialogues.text: You want me to do what? Aw, Soljak ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak is onto his next call ---  92.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: It’s just a test. We’re running a test. Yes, it’s been approved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busiest station in the city. This dispatcher, a woman, crushes a cigarette pack.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNE THE DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: Who orders a test at rush hour? Okay, Soljak, whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seagulls perch atop a lonely near-deserted modern tower i view of marshes and JFK Airport.

dialogues.speaker: HOWARD BEACH DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: I’m not the only one, am I? At what time ---? 6:20? The dispatcher looks at his clock: now it’s 6:11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cave-like, loud, the deepest station in the system. This dispatcher holds his head as he takes the call from Solja

dialogues.speaker: DEEP DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: If it’s gotta be done it’s gotta be done.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: They keep moving. Soljak keeps calling. Then, to Tupelo:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Say, when you were a kid did you ever take the subway?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: All the time. Rode right up front. Looking out the window. Why?

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What school you go to?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I went to private school. Why? Soljak puts a hand on Tupelo’s shoulder.  93.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just: “R-T,” you shoulda been nicer to the trains. Off Tupelo’s look, Soljak keeps rolling calls ---

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CONEY ISLAND/STILLWELL AVENUE TOWER
dialogues.text: In view of Nathan's, “The Cyclone” roller coaster and the beach. This elevated junction has multiple platforms bene a vaulted steel roof. A guy on the phone, SECOND IN COMMA does not comprehend:

dialogues.speaker: SECOND IN COMMAND
dialogues.text: I don’t know you or what you’re talking about but I’11 tell Bob.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Just tell Bob it’s Soljak, and tell him to cut power for two minutes at 6:20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN OLD BRICK BUILDING looks over the vast Maintenance Yar where subway cars return at the end of their runs to be washed, patched, and then sent out again.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RED BRICK BUILDING
dialogues.text: A small woman, MS. JOHNSON, stands in front of a big pane with 86 levers, her hands in motion like an orchestra conductor, she walks back and forth operating the switche that pump trains into the system. Someone hands her a pho

dialogues.speaker: MS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (as she works the levers) Why Mister Soljak, how is that big party they got going for you today? They must have lost my invitation.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: Soljak purrs into the phone for this call:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Why Ms. Johnson, so good to hear your voice. I have a tiny little favor to ask ---

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RED BRICK BUILDING
dialogues.text: The little woman stiffens:  94.

dialogues.speaker: MS. JOHNSON
dialogues.text: What are you drinking at that party? You want me to stop sending out trains?

dialogues.speaker: ON SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Like bitter sugar:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Just for one little minute. And --- I’m missing the party too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SITE OF THE BIG PARTY: balloons, bartenders serving egg c that damn “New York New York” song playing over and over and a giant cake in the shape of a new shuttle train. The at a podium with shuttle logo, makes a speech:

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: On a day when our coordinated efforts show that despite adver- sity there is no problem we can’t tackle, it’s my pleasure to cele- brate progress. This auspicious moment for the people of New York could never have happened without a team. There was the Governor --- APPLAUSE. THE GOVERNOR smiles. As the mayor next introduc DIGNITARIES, THE CAMERA SWEEPS PAST the balloons, band, P HILTON, reporters and cake, to FIND: TERRELL and MICHELLE

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: You gotta wait for him. He built this whole thing, he’s been wait- ing his whole life for this!

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Your boss has ruined my day.

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: But this is his party. The shiny new shuttle train eases into the station. Cheer and applause. The Mayor smiles proudly, jokes:

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: I am seeing something and I am saying something: Wow!  95.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: (to Terrell) He’s late. You see these reporters, those photographers? We are not go- ing to wait. By the way --- Now beside them: Bob the Reporter, who finishes her quest

dialogues.speaker: BOB THE REPORTER
dialogues.text: You ever find that train?

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Of course they found it. That was like ten hours ago. Old news.

dialogues.speaker: BOB THE REPORTER
dialogues.text: Where was it? As Terrell stalls, The Mayor wraps up his speech:

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: --- at last tying together The Bronx, Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens - sorry Staten Island, you're next, be patient. (that gets a laugh) And now for this medal, for the one person who has been with this project from the start --- The Mayor looks to Michelle: who do I give this to? She shrugs: he’s not here. So ---

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This special city medal goes to the one person without whom there would be no shuttle --- and certainly no party today. Let’s all salute --- (he’s got to give it to someone---) Michelle Murphy! FLASH POPS as a proud Michelle goes to the podium to acce Soljak’s medal as her own. PICTURES! PICTURES! PICTURES!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s all ride the shuttle! The mayor, governor, senators, reporters and photographer and of course Michelle, all press into the train.  96.

dialogues.speaker: TERRELL
dialogues.text: No! You gotta wait for Soljak--- But Terrell is ignored as generators and compressors fire

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Stand clear of the closing doors. A ding-dong chime and the doors close. There’s a triumpha blow of the train’s horn --- CONDUCTOR (CONT ’D) Next stop - Brooklyn! LOUD CHEERS from within the train as the shuttle train pu of the station, disappearing around a curve and leaving T alone on the platform surrounded by balloons and cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dirt-red setting sun fights with dark rain clouds. Dist thunder. Tupelo and Soljak are pushing their way through crowded, chaotic streets. It’s a few blocks to DeKalb Sta master control for Brooklyn. Tupelo splits off to the rig

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Where you think you’re going?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Gotta catch a train at Bergen Street.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Whoa! No. That station’s too dangerous. I shut it down. You can’t go there.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: (keeps moving) My wife --- I’ve got to.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: (chases him, holds him) You can’t! I’m pumping the energy of this whole system into that one stretch - if we do get it back --- maybe you don’t wanna be there.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I have to be there. I should have been on that train, should have stayed on it. If I had - my weight, mass - maybe it would have been different - but I gotta be there now. No matter what. With her.  97.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: But those people - after twelve hours, what’s ---?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: It could be over for them. The stress of the passage - or maybe they’re or in some kind of suspend- ed time - everything that ever happened in that tunnel could be wrapped around like a loop - or maybe it’s pure terror or ---

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Sometimes when I don’t know an answer you know what I say? - “I don’t know.” What’s her name?

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: My wife? “Renee.” And yeah: I know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Good luck. Tupelo dashes down into the Atlantic Avenue Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo rushes towards the end of the platform. He ignores DANGER! DO NOT ENTER! - climbs over the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo runs along the dark narrow ledge towards the glowi lights of the Bergen Street Station - a quarter mile away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak stands at the main board, barks into a headset:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: Okay, Morrissey. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morrissey throws a switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A substation feeding power to the rails. Its motors shut  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power shuts down along this sector of track - as all trai stop WE SEE A FLASH OF SPARKS AND SMOKE and then a SHIMME OF ELECTRICITY RETREATING BACK TOWARDS MANHATTAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo runs hard along the wall ledge - but the ledge sto hundred yards short of Bergen Street Station. He climbs o the safety railing, drops down into the track bed, runs towards the lights at the end of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SNAKE OF SPARKS FLASHES along the path of the elevated track then WHOOSHES down into THE BROADWAY IRT TUNNEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SIZZLE OF BLUE-SPARKING DC CURRENT and A POWERFUL WIND SWEEPS PAST the 116th Street/Columbia University station

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The relays are clicking-smoking like crazy, but there’s n visible trains running here! - only that FLASH OF ENERGY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little red lights on control boards go dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manhattan skyline in the distance. Passengers waiting on elevated platform see the tracks that curve past Shea Sta then dip down into the Corona Subway Tunnel. A train head for the station from the other direction. Grinds to a hal when the power is cut. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: THE ENTIRE ELEVATED PLATFORM BEGINS TO SHAKE -
dialogues.text: --- RAILS VIBRATING and sending out A BASS NOTE SO DEEP i causes the people on the platform to gasp for air as ---

dialogues.speaker: A CRACKLE OF LIGHTNING ---
dialogues.text: --- EXPLODES out from the Corona Tunnel - shoots towards Stadium Station and the now-stalled train - then SCREECHE a STOP as if hitting an invisible wall and instantly ROCK back towards Manhattan.  99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo, running towards the eerie glow of Bergen Street Station - can FEEL the POWER coursing through the system overhead pipes THROBBING, tracks GROANING and RATTLING.

dialogues.speaker: WE FOLLOW THE BLUE-SPARKING, SCREECHING, SEARING-HOT CURR
dialogues.text: --- SLAMMING US BACK INTO OUR SEATS as it races 10-20-30 miles in an instant - RICOCHETING BACK FROM INVISIBLE WAL (where the power’s been cut) - trying every way to escape

dialogues.speaker: SPARKS AND WIND WHIPPING PAST 468 STATIONS -
dialogues.text: --- in the span of a few seconds - from SOUTH FERRY at th south tip of Manhattan up to PELHAM BAY in the Bronx, out to QUEENS PLAZA, then blasting back through TIMES SQUARE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soljak watches the big board that shows the entire New Yo City Subway System - red lights are now dark in the Bronx Queens, and TURNING OFF LIKE A DESCENDING CURTAIN in Manh tan --- THE LIGHTS ON THE BOARD GOING DARK IN SOUTHEAST BROOKLYN - all that remains glowing now is

dialogues.speaker: THE MOEBIUS KNOT
dialogues.text: of the interlocked subways lines that all converge in Brooklyn - and one slim line of lights that trails south Coney Island. Soljak points to that still-glowing line:

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What the - shut down Coney Island!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BLUE ARC OF FLAME that carries THE ENERGY STORM is no

dialogues.speaker: A THRILL RIDE WHIPPING AROUND THE MOEBIUS KNOT/POWER SPOT
dialogues.text: tries to find its way out of THE TWISTING MAZE OF SUBWAY AND TUNNELS, every escape route closing, directing ALL TH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deserted. Gates locked. Tupelo reaches the pit in front o the platform, reaches to a ladder, HEARS THE ONCOMING ROA OF THE PULSING ENERGY STORM and ---  100.

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO IS HIT WITH A WALL OF POWER AND WIND
dialogues.text: that knocks him down onto the tracks -

dialogues.speaker: AT THE SAME SPOT HE FELL IN THE MORNING ---
dialogues.text: --- debris and muck flying - again he loses his glasses - the power blasts past him ---

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: Renee---!1!!

dialogues.speaker: THE POWER PASSES THROUGH THE STATION
dialogues.text: and disappears into the southbound darkness. Tupelo react No Renee. No train. Alone between the vibrating tracks he pounds the wooden ties with his fists - emotional agony: his plan failed - the train with car #8686 did not return

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All lights are dark on the map of the city - except for Bergen Street and that string of lights south to Coney Island. Soljak smacks the board.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: What the hell’s going on!?

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: They won’t shut it down at Coney -- - the special train’s out there, the mayor’s train.

dialogues.speaker: SOLJAK
dialogues.text: It’s not HIS train, it’s MINE! Soljak rips the metal cover off a circuit control board, reaches in and tears out a handful of wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The electrified 3rd rail goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train stops with a jolt. People tumble, knocking over party food and drink trays. The generator stops. The mayo huh? - lights go out, everyone groans, then we hear ---

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Michelle! !!! Outside the window of the now-dark special subway shuttle  101. only thing still running on rails in Coney Island is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People screaming, arms in the air, as they shoot down and around the old wooden coaster’s gravity-controlled tracks

dialogues.speaker: THE BOLT OF LIGHTNING ROARS TOWARDS CONEY ISLAND AND THE
dialogues.text: MAYOR’S NOW-DARK SHUTTLE TRAIN, STOPS INCHES FROM SLAMMIN INTO THE SHUTTLE TRAIN, INSTANTLY REVERSES and---

dialogues.speaker: SCREECHES BACK TOWARDS BERGEN STREET
dialogues.text: along the ELEVATED ROUTE, TEARING A WAVE OF SPIKES OUT OF TRACKS, SPIKES RAINING DOWN ONTO THE STREETS BELOW as THE OF POWER arcs down into the subway tunnel under Prospect «+. the park now lit by a PHOSPHORESCENT GLOW as ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo sees the ONCOMING STORM-WAVE OF POWER BLASTING RIG AT HIM - the rails white-hot, the wind and pressure ---

dialogues.speaker: DRAWING POWER FROM THE ENTIRE GRID OF THE SUBWAY SYSTEM
dialogues.text: shaking loose pipes and spikes and wires and now Tupelo i

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CENTER OF A HURRICANE -
dialogues.text: force and power swirling around him faster and faster and noise ROARING, Tupelo being cut by the sizzling swirling steel dust, wires igniting and steam pipes bursting and

dialogues.speaker: EVERYTHING LOUDER AND LOUDER AND THEN ---
dialogues.text: SILENCE --- and then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tupelo, is inside subway car 8686 holding onto the pole f balance, looking up at the old SUBWAY BEAUTY CONTEST POST He hears the SCREECH of wheels. Then he sees:  102.

dialogues.speaker: A PREP SCHOOL KID
dialogues.text: back turned to him, at the front --- carving initials int the door: R-T TUPELO TRIES TO MOVE - HE CAN’T - HE LOOKS OUT THE WINDOW Running parallel on a parallel track is a different subwa train - A 1940'S-STYLE TRAIN with Casablanca-type ceiling fans, filled with people dressed in 1940’s style ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parallel subway train edges sideways now, MOVING CLOS AND CLOSER to the train Tupelo is riding in - Tupelo GRIP the pole, BRACES for a collision but instead ---

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO TRAINS SOFTY CONVERGE ---
dialogues.text: --- becoming one overlapped train in overlapped dimension

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO IS NOW INSIDE BOTH TRAINS ---
dialogues.text: --- folded into each other on A TRIP THROUGH FOUR-DIMENSI SPACE WHERE TIME AND SURFACE WARP AND WRAP through each o as if liquids mixing - a stewing cauldron of images - the famous “WHO WILL BE MISS SUBWAY?” ads floating through ai people long since gone shifting in and out of focus as

dialogues.speaker: THE TRAIN ITSELF CHANGES ---
dialogues.text: ---its windows now in the shape of portholes, its color scheme an art deco red and grey, morphing in and out of e style of train that has ever run on these tracks - a WOOD CAR FROM 1904 - Tupelo among men in straw hats - NOW IT’S 60'S - bellbottoms, big Afros - the train plastered with graffiti - NOW THE TRAIN IS PACKED WITH PASSENGERS going Coney Island in the 1920’s - all these overlaps fading as

dialogues.speaker: SHAPE OF THE UNIVERSE ---
dialogues.text: --- the train turning in on itself without tearing, turni inside out --- without upsetting the point of reference occupied by Richard Tupelo who sees:

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Sitting at the end of the train---  103.

dialogues.speaker: --- AS THEY DETOUR THROUGH FOUR-DIMENSIONAL SPACE,
dialogues.text: Renee tranquil amidst the sounds of STORMS and EXPLOSIONS STEEL WHEELS SCREECHING and SUBWAY DRUMMERS and now ---

dialogues.speaker: RENEE IS HOLDING AN INFANT WRAPPED IN A BLANKET ---
dialogues.text: Tupelo moves to her. Touches her cheek. Renee looks up:

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: Don’t be afraid. --- they look down together at the cooing, giggling child observing this wonderful show of light, shape and color. longer are there metal edges, plastic veneer, aluminum po and vents dripping condensation, INSTEAD ---

dialogues.speaker: THE INFANT SEES
dialogues.text: EXTRAORDINARY PATTERNS and SPECTRUMS of LIQUID CRYSTAL LI and COLORS UNIMAGINABLE --- --- with SPIRALLING PATTERNS of SNOW-FLAKE FRACTALS and c ing WAVE FORMS in a sea of COMETARY KNOTS (the tadpole-li particle residue of dying stars) and CLOUDS OF ATOMS --- --- all wrapped in a MICROWAVE-SUPERNOVA GLOW of more-and complex MOEBIUS STRIPS --- a primal vision of beauty and sensual reality, the world unseen.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE REACHES OUT TO TUPELO,
dialogues.text: takes his hand:

dialogues.speaker: RENEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were right, Richard. She lived - she saw the world, this world, the world we’ve forgotten, and she saw it and had a wonderful little life, a beautiful life, with the most beautiful visions and experi- ences - she had all that - and all our love --- and she lived. Tupelo touches the baby, and now, with Renee smiling, he starts to cry --- has held in so much, now his release --

dialogues.speaker: TUPELO
dialogues.text: I miss her so much. I miss us.  104.

dialogues.speaker: RENEE
dialogues.text: I know Richard. But we did good. She was happy. She lived. He leans down to kiss her ---

dialogues.speaker: THEIR LIPS MEET
dialogues.text: ---one long beautiful kiss - one long unimaginable expres of love - which alters space and time --- and now:

dialogues.speaker: RENEE IS STANDING BESIDE HIM,
dialogues.text: No child, the two of them together, same spot they were i when they argued on the train in the morning -

dialogues.speaker: NOW THEY ARE KISSING,
